loans.name: Hok's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Hok P. is the leader of this four-member group; all the borrowers live in Siem Reap Commune of Siem Reap Province. P. is currently a fish seller; she sells the catch from her husband's fishing and sometimes buys from wholesalers to sell retail in Psa Kroam Market. She is married to Chan Thoeun, 39, who is a local fisherman. She is the mother of seven children, all of whom are single. Two of her children are employed as garment workers.

Fishing is Thoeun's main source to earn the money to support his family's expense adequately. Recently, Thoeun can't catch as many fish as before because his fishing implements have broken, so he had a discussion with his wife and decided to ask for a loan to buy more fishing implements.

The other three borrowers are:

S., 45, sells Khmer noodles. She needs a loan to purchase rice seed for her husband to grow.

P., age 44, sells meatballs in the market. She is asking for a loan to buy nets and traps for her husband for fishing.

S., 43, is a grocery seller. She requests a loan to buy different varieties of groceries to sell.

loans.use: to buy more fishing implements

loans.name: Brak

texts.en: Brak S., 32, a married mother of three, lives in Prey Chor District, Kampong Cham Province, where her husband earns approximately $3 each day making incense. Brak is now requesting a loan of $1000 to increase incense production to meet client demand.

loans.use: To make incense.

loans.name: Touy

texts.en:
Touy C., a 37-year-old mother of three children, currently works as a rice farmer, earning about $2 a day. Her husband, a construction worker who builds houses, earns about $3 a day.

Touy is requesting a loan of $1000 to begin a new business. She will use this money to rent a cashew nut farm, and believes that this loan will help her to improve her family's standard of living and move her closer to fulfilling her dreams.

loans.use: To rent a cashew nut farm.

loans.name: Ni Nengah Ngalis

texts.id: Setelah pelunasan dari periode pertama pinjamannya, Ni Nengah Ngalis kembali mengajukan pinjaman kedua yang jumlahnya sebesar Rp. 2. 000. 000,-. Dana yang diperoleh akan dimanfaatkan untuk biaya produksi yang meliputi : ongkos tukang panjat kelapa dan memperbaharui alat untuk produksi gula merah ( wajan dan alat cetak ). Dengan  alat- alat produksi yang baru, Ni Nengah Ngalis berharap, produksi gula merahnya dapat meningkat serta bentuk/desainnya sesuai dengan yang diminta oleh pasar. Dari keuntungan usaha gula merah yang ia lakukan, Ni Nengah Gelis akan menyisihkan setengahnya untuk biaya renovasi rumah dan setengahnya lagi untuk membeli sebuah kendaraan bermotor yang dapat dimanfaatkan sebagai alat angkut gula merahnya ke pasar.
texts.en:
After paying off her first loan, Ni Nengah Ngalis is requesting a second loan for 2,000,000 IDR. The fund will be used to cover production costs such as the fee for the coconut tree climber and to renew her palm sugar production equipment (pans and baking tins). With new production equipments, Ni Nengah Ngalis hopes to improve her production capacity and to be able to offer palm sugar in shapes/designs that the market wants. Ni Nengah Gelis will set aside half of her profit to purchase a motor vehicle that can be used to transport her palm sugar to the nearby market.

Translated from Indonesian by Arliadi (Ludi) Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay her employees and to buy new equipments

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Keo O., 64 years old, is the mother of five children and lives in Kampong Cham Province.  She and her husband earn less than $1/day growing rice, but also receive support from their employed children, one of whom works as a housekeeper in Malaysia, three as garment factory workers, and the last one as a clothing vendor in a busy market. 

Keo is requesting a loan to purchase a clothes marketing stand in the market so as to reduce her daughter’s monthly vending costs.

loans.use: To purchase a clothes stand in the market.

loans.name: Chear

texts.en: Mrs. Chear S., 29 years old and the mother of two children, lives with her husband in Kampong Cham, Cambodia, where she earns around $3/day selling fish in a local market; her husband, a construction worker who builds houses, earns about $5 a day. Chear is requesting a loan to purchase a motorbike to transport the fish to market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Sreng

texts.en:
Sreng K., 22, pictured with her husband and her mom, lives with her husband and children in Prey Chor District, Kampong Cham, Cambodia, where she grows and sells rice, earning around $2 a day; her husband is a banana seller at the market, making about $6 a day.

Sreng is requesting a loan of $1000 to rent a banana farm in order to expand her business activites.

loans.use: To rent a banana farm.

loans.name: Sayu Kade Puspa

texts.id:
Sayu Kade Puspa dalam keseharian hidupnya  membantu suami dalam menambah penghasilan keluarga melalui usaha warungnya  yang berada di depan rumahnya .
Dengan tambahan modal dari DINARI yang merupakan pinjaman untuk periode pertama, Sayu Kade Puspa  bisa menambah jumlah jenis barang yang akan dijual kepada pembeli yang bisa meningkatkan hasil penjualan dan dan juga keuntungan bersih dari hasil usahanya. Sayu Kade Puspa bermaksud untuk melanjutkan pinjaman periode ke dua dengan jangka waktu 12 bulan dengan pembayaran dilunasi pada akhir periode pinjaman. Sehingga dengan tambahan modal tersebut mereka dapat meningkatkan jumlah persediaan barang daganganya yang akan di jual sehingga keuntungan yang diperoleh akan lebih meningkat guna penunjang pendapatan keluarganya.
texts.en:
Sayu Kade Puspa helps her husband to provide additional income for the family by running a small shop in front of their house. With additional capital from DINARI, which was her first loan, Sayu Kade Puspa could add variety to the items she sold to her customers which in turns led to increase sales and profits. Sayu Kade Puspa is planning to continue with her second loan with 12 months term, paid in full at the end of the period. With additional capital they can further add more units to the stocks and increase profit to support the family.

Translated from Indonesian by Arliadi (Ludi) Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to add working capital

loans.name: Sout

texts.en:
Sout S., who is married and living in Kampong Cham with her husband and children, has been selling rice since 2000 to earn a living, making upwards of $5 a day; her husband operates a motor-taxi and raises domestic animals to earn additional income.

Sout is requesting a loan to purchase rice for resale, confident that this will allow her to increase her income and raise her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase rice for resale.

loans.name: San

texts.en:
San R., 43, lives with her husband and child in Kampong Cham, where she grows and sells rice, making around $3.50 a day, while her husband has businesses grinding rice crops and making rice wine from home. On average, he makes $3 a day.

San is requesting a loan to purchase rice for resale, confident that this will be an effective means by which to increase her income and raise her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase rice for resale.

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en: Soeun N., 36, a widowed farmer who grows and sells yams, lives in Kampong Cham with her child, who is a student, and generally makes about $5 a day. She is requesting this loan to purchase fertilizer for her farmland.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer.

loans.name: Ni Putu Arianti

texts.id: Ni Putu Arianti Adalah Ibu Rumah tangga yang kesehariannya melakukan usaha warung di rumahnya mulai pagi hari sampai dengan sore hari sambil melakukan kewajibanya sebagai seorang istri yang merawat anaknya yang baru berumur 3 Tahun. Untuk menambah macam daganganya Ni Putu Arianti mengajukan pinjaman dana ke DINARI sebesar Rp 6 000 000,-yang pengembalianya pada akhir jangka waktu pinjaman yang jangka waktunya  12 bulan, dengan harapan semakin banyak barang dagangan yang di jual maka pelanggan akan lebih banyak yang akan membeli ke tempatnya. Dengan demikian Ni Putu Arianti akan mendapatkan keuntungan yang lebih banyak guna menunjang penghasilan keluarganya untuk masa depan Anak –anak mereka.
texts.en:
Ni Putu Arianti is a homemaker who is also running a small shop in her house from the morning through the afternoon while taking care of her 3 years old child. To add variety to her selling goods, Ni Putu Arianti is requesting 6,000,000 IDR loan to DINARI which will be paid in full at the end of the 12 months term. She hopes that the more goods she sells will bring more customers. Hence Ni Putu Arianti will earn larger profit to support her family’s income and for the future of their children.

Translated from Indonesian by Arliadi (Ludi) Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more merchandise

loans.name: Van

texts.en:
Van S., 46, is married and lives with her husband and two children, one of whom is a student, in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 2000, she and her spouse have operated a grocery store, earning about $7 each day. 

Van is now requesting a loan of $1000 to expand the store by purchasing more items to meet client demand.  Her husband and daughter are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To expand her grocery store.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mao H., 59, lives in Pursat province, Cambodia. She has owned a plot of land since 1999. She grows both rice and vegetable crops. She can plant her crops twice a year, in the dry season and the rainy season--a skill she learned from her grandparents. She is married to Him Hoeun, 64, who is a domestic marble carver. He normally collects marble from the mountains to make statues, carving and selling them out of his house.

His business is going very well with a lot of customers recognizing the quality of his statues. The couple has four children; three of them are single and one is married. Two of H.'s daughters are employed as garment workers. Since statue-carving is their main source of income, H. and Hoeun are applying for a loan as capital to purchase a carving machine to use to carve the marble blocks.

loans.use: to purchase a carving machine to use to carve the marble blocks

loans.name: Khuy

texts.en:
Khuy K. is 42 years old and lives in Kampong Cham with her husband and six of her children. She raises pigs and makes about US$ 2 a day. Her husband, pictured here, is a professional carpenter in the village. He produces wooden windows, doors, chairs, tables and other furniture. On average, he earns around US$ 5 every day. Two of their children are employed, while two are students and the last one is too young to attend school.

Mrs. Khuy K. is asking for a loan to purchase wood and a sawing machine for her husband to expand the business.

loans.use: To purchase wood and a sawing machine.

loans.name: Pa

texts.en: Pa L. is 43 years old, a house wife, and lives in Kampong Cham with her husband and four of her children. She stays at home doing housework and cooking for her family members. Her husband is a head of family who desires to earn an income to support the family. He runs a small restaurant selling wine, roast beef and pork. On average, he makes about US$6 a day. Two of their children are employed and two others are students. This family would like to use the loan to purchase utensils and more food products to increase the business.

loans.use: To purchase utensils.

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Sim E. grows yam and catches fish to earn a living. She is able to earn US$2 a day. She lives in Kampong Cham and she has been operating her business for about 4 years. Her husband, Ry Thorn, is a recycler and earns US$4 a day. The couple has six children, three of who are students and the rest are too young to attend school. Mrs. Sim E. would like to use this loan to hire farm workers to harvest and plow her land.

loans.use: Hire workers to plow and grow yams.

loans.name: Nao

texts.en:
Nao K., 22, is married and lives with her husband, in Kampong Cham She is able to earn US$2.5 everyday as a pig breeder, while her husband is a farmer and grows rice and yam. On average, he earns US$2 a day. This couple has one child who is too young to attend school. 

Mrs. Nao K. would like to take out a loan of US$500 to hire farm workers harvest and plow land.

loans.use: To hire farm workers harvest and plow land.

loans.name: Ul

texts.en:
Ul C. is 60 years old and lives in Pursat Province, Cambodia. She is a widow and earns a living raising pigs in a stall behind her house. She sells the pigs for slaughter six months after she begins raising them. 

She can raise litters twice per year and has been raising pigs more than 24 years. She learned the skill from her grandfather. For additional income, she also sells fish. 

She currently has four children; three of them are married and the other one is single. Two of her children are employed: one is a fish seller and other one is a fisherman. In order to make the business successful, C. has applied for a loan to buy more piglets to raise and some fish to sell.

loans.use: To buy more piglets to raise and some fish to sell

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Sim C. is 35 years old, a widow, and lives with her parents and her young child in Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer and sells small freshwater shells in the local market. She makes about US$3 a day.

Mrs. Sim C. would like to take out a loan of US$1,200 to make a new investment. She will rent a yam farm and collect the produce to sell at the market as a wholesaler.

loans.use: To rent a yam farm.

loans.name: Ang

texts.en: Ang M., 48, pictured with her daughter, is a widow who stays at home doing house work. She lives with two of her daughters. The family is aided by one daughter who runs a grocery store and generally makes about US$4 each day. Mrs. Ang M. is asking for loan of US$1,000 to expand the grocery store by adding more products to meet her clients' demands.

loans.use: To expand grocery store.

loans.name: Misriah

texts.id: Misriah, 35 tahun, tinggal dipesisir pantai. Sebagai seorang istri nelayan, Misriah menekuni usaha jual beli ikan. Disamping menjual ikan segar, Misriah juga menjual ikan Teri ( ikan kecil yang dikeringkan ). Usaha ini ditekuninya untuk menunjang usaha utamanya menjual ikan segar yang didapat olegh suaminya. Untuk meningkatkan usahanya, Misriah memerlukan dana sebesar Rp. 1.000.000.- Dana ini dipergunakan untuk membeli lebih banyak lagi ikan kecil dari nelayan yang lain. Setelah dibersihkan dan dijemur sampai kering, harga per kilo Rp. 10.000.- Dalam seminggu Misriah bisa menjual 10 kilo ikan Teri. Dengan tambahan dana yang didapatnya, Misriah berharap dalam seminggu dia bisa menjual 20 kilo ikan Teri.
texts.en:
35 years old Misriah lives by a sea shore. As a fisherman’s wife, Misriah trades fish. In addition to selling fresh fish, Misriah also sells small dried fish. She runs this business to support her primary business of selling fresh fish caught by her husband. To take her business to the next level, Misriah needs 1,000,000 IDR. This fund will be used to buy more small dried fish from other fishermen. After cleaning and drying, the fish can be sold for 10,000 IDR per kilogram. In a week Misriah can sell 10 kilograms of small dried fish. With additional capital Misriah hopes to sell 20 kilograms of small dried fish in a week.

Translated from Indonesian by Arliadi (Ludi) Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more fish

loans.name: Yun

texts.en:
Yun H. is 51 years old and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She opened a laundry shop in her small house to earn a living and is able to make US$3 a day. 

Her husband operates a moto-taxi. He typically makes US$3 every day as well. This couple has four children and all of them are employed with different jobs. 

One of Mrs. Yun’s sons is a mechanic and fixes cars. Mrs. Yun H. is asking for a loan to purchase mechanic tools for her son.

loans.use: To purchase mechanic tools for her son.

loans.name: Seang

texts.en: Seang S., age 37, is married and lives in Kampong Cham. She makes and sells fermented fish in a busy market and is able to make around US$10  in revenue every day. She has had her business since she was single. Her husband stays at home and helps make the fermented fish. This couple has two school-aged children. Mrs. Seang S. wants to use this loan to make more fermented fish to sell.

loans.use: To make more fermented fish to sell.

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Kim L., 57, is a widow who lives in Kampong Cham with her child. She is a true entrepreneur who operates a grocery store from her home. She sells various kinds of goods and is able to make approximately $7.50 USD every day. She is aided by her child, who works as a worker and make $5.00 USD each day. 

Mrs. Kim L. would like to take a loan of $1000 USD to rebuild her store, add groceries to her inventory, and purchase rice to resell.

loans.use: To rebuild her store, add groceries, and purchase rice to resell.

loans.name: Nanu Chori

texts.en:
Mrs. Nanu Chori M., a resident of Thecho, lives in single family with her husband and one son. Thecho is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur and most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Her husband, Mr. Buddi Bhakta M., works in a private office. Her son is ninth months old.

Mrs. M. is engaged in goat farming. She has four goats in her farm. She sells the goats in the local market. This business helps her to contribute something to improve the living standards of her family. 

She is requesting her first loan of Rs 10000.00 to buy few more goats and foods grains for the goats. She is planning to save her income to provide a good education for her son because, in Nepal, the cost of education is very high.

loans.use: To buy few more goats

loans.name: Herman

texts.id: Herman menekuni usaha bengkel jual beli dan pasang ban untuk mobil dan sepeda motor. Hal ini sesuai dengan pendidikannya yang lulusan Sekolah Tehnik Mesin. Saat ini ia tinggal bersama istri dan anaknya lelaki yang juga membantunya dalam menjalani usaha ini. Usahanya berkembang setelah ia memutuskan untuk menjual tempat tinggalnya yang lama dan berpindah ke lokasi baru yang tempatnya sangat strategis yakni di penggir jalan utama yang menghubungkan Denpasar dan Gilimanuk. Karena merupakan jalan utama, banyak kendaraan yang melintas di tempat usahanya. Seringkali Herman merasa kewalahan karena usahanya masih kecil dan tidak bisa melayani kebutuhan pelanggan dengan baik. Untuk mengatasi hal itu, Herman membutuhkan dana sebesar Rp. 5.000.000.- untuk mengembangkan usahanya. Dana itu akan dipergunakan untuk membeli aneka jenis dan ukuran ban serta sebuah dongkrak untuk mengangkat mobil yang besar. Herman optimis usahanya akan berkembang dengan baik, karena ia percaya dengan layanan yang baik kepada pelanggan, mereka akan puas dan akan datang kembali ke bengkelnya dengan lebih banyak pelanggan baru.
texts.en:
Herman is in the vehicle service repair business buying, selling and installing tires for cars and motor cycles. This is in line with his education as Engine Technical school graduate. Today he stays with wife and son, who also helps him in running the business. The business grew after he decided to sell his living quarters, and move to a new very strategic location on the side of main road between Denpasar and Gilimanuk. Since it is on the main road, many vehicles pass through his business. Many times Herman felt overloaded, since his business is still small and could not give enough service. To solve it, Herman needs capital for Rp. 5,000,000.- (translator's note: 1US$ fluctuates between Rp 10,000-12,000) to expand his business. That funds would be used to buy several assortments of size and type/brand of tires, and also equipment to lift large cars. Herman is optismic that his business could expand well, since he is confident about his good service to his clients, and they would be satisfied and would return to his shop with more new clients.

Translated from Indonesian by Gwan Ang, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more type and size of tires

loans.name: Mob

texts.en:
Mob H. makes a living as a farmer, and currently lives in Pursat Province, Cambodia. She is 53 years old. She has been growing rice and vegetables since 1981, a skill that she learned from her grandparents. 

She is married to Pak Sou, age 55, who works with her growing crops. H. has five children, two of them are single and the others are married. To help her with the hard physical labor, two of her children work with her on her farm. 

In the past, she rented a buffalo from a farmer to help her with her farm work. She now wants to own a buffalo, so she is applying for a loan to buy a water buffalo to help her plow her farmland and so she can raise its offspring.

loans.use: To buy a water buffalo

loans.name: Chun

texts.en:
Chun L., who is pictured with her daughter, is 52 years old. She is a widowed farmer who lives with three of her children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. She purchases and sells rice and makes about US $5.00 per day. The family is aided by one of her daughters, who has a business selling various kinds of desserts from home and is able to make US$ 10.00 each day in revenue. Her other two children are students. 

Mrs. Chun L. is asking for a loan of US $1000 to expand her rice stock.She will purchase rice and take off the husk with the intention of reselling the rice and turning over a profit. She is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a tool to increase her income and raise her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase rice for sale.

loans.name: Hosiyat

texts.ru:
Саидова Хосият Икромовна 1975 года рождения, замужем, имеет 5 детей. Предпринимательством занимается пять лет и на данный момент торгует продуктами питания в городе Душанбе. Ассортимент продаваемого товара состоит из кондитерских изделий, разновидностей консервной продукции, продуктов детского питания, разных сливочных и хлопковых масел, сахара, хлеба, колбасных изделий и т.д. Свой товар закупает в оптовых магазинах «Сафар-Центр» - а города Душанбе.
Хосият нужны средства для проведения свадебного мероприятия дочери и чтоб ее активы в бизнесе не уменьшились, она решила воспользоваться дополнительными средствами и хочет получить займ в сумме 3000 сомони.
texts.en:
Born in 1975, Hosiyat S. is married and has 5 children. She has been an entrepreneur for five years and currently sells food products in Dushanbe. Her product assortment consists of sweets, various canned food, children’s food, butter and oils, sugar, bread, sausages and other products. She purchases her goods at wholesale stores Safar-Centr in Dushanbe. Hosiyat needs funds to hold a wedding reception for her daughter. She does not want to reduce her business assets and decided to obtain this $875 loan.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To hold daughter's wedding reception

loans.name: Nakali

texts.en:
Mrs. Nakali M. lives in Thecho. Thecho is located in Lalitpur district and most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Mrs. M. lives in joint family with her father-in-law, mother-in-law, husband, brother-in-law and one daughter.

Mrs. Nikita and her husband Mr. Raju opened their sandal shop six years ago. They sell different types of sandals in their shop. 

Mrs. M. is requesting her first loan of Rs 10000.00 to buy different varieties of sandals for their shop.

loans.use: To buy sandals

loans.name: Ramzana M. Rasheed Group

texts.en:
My name is Ramzana and I am a 45-year-old married woman. I have lived in Arifwala, Pakistan for 21 years. I am married to M. R., and he has run a grocery shop near our community for the past 5 years. I am a mother of four children: two sons and two daughters. None of the children go to school. 

Ramzana baji belongs to a family of farmers, so she knows how to take care of animals. Presently, she has one buffalo and, from her, she collects milk and sells in the milk shop. She is applying for a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.  

She is a the leader of a group of women in her locality. Zubaida baji wants a loan to buy vegetables to resell. Kaniz baji wants a loan to buy lentils, cooking oil and spices for her food business. Bashiran baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Zainab baji wants a loan to rent land on contract to grow vegetables to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: 'Baji,' which means 'older sister,' is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy groceries for her grocery shop

loans.name: Chub

texts.en: Chub S., age 53, is a true entrepreneur who resides in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She has been operating her grocery store since 2001 and is able to make about US $6 every day. Her husband sells used clothing in a busy market. On average, he makes US $6 per day. This couple has four children, three of who are employed as garment factory workers. Mrs Chub S. would like to use this loan to add to her grocery store inventory and to meet her clients' demands.

loans.use: To add to her grocery store inventory

loans.name: Sarmila

texts.en:
Sarmila M. lives with her husband and two sons in Thecho, Lalitpur. Thecho is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur. Her older son is studying in grade 4 and younger son is in pre-primary school.

Mrs. M. and her husband, Saroj M., make different types of traditional brass religious figures, as per the demands of their customers. With her first loan from Kiva, she bought wax, metal, and other materials needed to mold and finish her idols. Now she is requesting a second loan from Kiva of Rs 15000.00 to buy necessary raw material for her statues. She plans to continue making the statues and improving her efficiency over the time.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her work

loans.name: Shabana Group

texts.en:
Shabana is the group leader of the Shabana group. There are three members in this group. Each of them would like to receive money for her business.

Shakaba and Shabana want to take a loan for their husbands' fruit cart businesses and they want to buy necessary materials for their businesses. Also, Hanefa wants to take a loan for her business of beading. She wants to complete her stock. They are requesting a loan of 42000 Afghani for a term of 9 months.

They want to say that this loan is very useful because this loan can provide a good chance for poor entrepreneurs to expand their businesses.

loans.use: to complete their stock

loans.name: Plong

texts.en:
Plong S., age 56, is pictured with her husband. She is married and lives in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. She has been selling clothes in a busy market since 2001 and is able to make US $10 every day. Her husband is a construction foreman in the village. He builds wooden and cement houses. On average, he makes US $10 a day. This couple also get support from their three children, who work as garment factory workers. 

Mrs. Plong S. would like to take a loan to purchase construction tools for her husband. This will allow her husband to access larger construction projects.

loans.use: To purchase construction tools.

loans.name: Safarali

texts.ru:
Мадбобоев Сафарали Азамжонович  1961 года рождения, женат, имеет ребенка. Он разводит телят и коров. Сафарали покупает телят на рынке за низкую цену, затем кормит их и перепродает их на том же самом рынке за более выгодную цену. Ему помогает жена  с этим бизнесом.  Он упорно трудится, чтобы сделать бизнес успешным и произвести устойчивый доход для семьи. Этим он занимается 3 года. Теперь, Сафарали планирует купить трех телят. 
Он хочет получить займ в сумме 3000 сроком на 10 месяцев. Развитие его бизнеса находится в Ваших руках.
texts.en:
Born in 1961, Safarali M. is married and has a child. He raises cattle. Safarali buys calves at a market at low prices, then raises them and sells them at the same market but at higher prices. His wife helps him out with the business. Safarali works very hard for his business to succeed and bring stable income for his family. He has been in this business for 3 years. Now he plans to purchase three calves and obtain a 10-month $875 loan for this purpose. Growth of his business is in your hands.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of three calves

loans.name: Bashiran Sabir Ali Group

texts.en:
Bashiran baji is a 52 years old married lady and has resided in a city named Arifwala, Pakistan, for the past 12 years. Her husband name is S. A., who is a driver of a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). She is the mother of six children: four sons and two daughters. Her elder son has a food selling business. The next to him is a driver and drives a rented auto-rickshaw. The others are not employed. Bashiran baji belongs to an agriculture profession. She takes care of the land of land owners and earns income. She invests her income in a committee and plans to renovate her house when she saves the right amount. She is applying for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw for her son, so that he able to earn a larger income. 

She is part of a group loan of several women in her locality. Kalsoom baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Majidan baji wants a loan to buy shaving creams and razors for her barbershop. Shazia baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw. Irshad baji wants a loan to buy material (sugar, dry fruits) for her sweetmeat making business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Rukmani

texts.en:
Mrs. Rukmani T., 51 years old, is a tailor in the town of Tangal, in Patan. She opened her tailoring shop 31 years ago. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies dresses and school uniforms for both boys and girls. She prefers to make popular dresses like Kurta Sulwar, blouses, ladies long dresses, Makhshi, and others. 
Before starting her own business, Mrs. Tamarkar took a 6 month training course in tailoring. She plans to use the loan of Rs 20000 to buy raw materials for her tailoring work. She wants to add to her family's income and support her children's education. With her previous loan from kiva she is able to buy necessary raw materials for her work.
She is separated from her husband Rabindra Kumar T., so she is solely responsible for the family. She has one son and two daughters. They are now studying.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her work

loans.name: Shova

texts.en:
Mrs. Shova S. lives in Bholdhoka, Lalitpur. She has three sons and a daughter. Her daughter is married. Her  two older sons are studying for their BBS (Bachelor in Business Study) and her younger son is studying in grade 10.
Both Mrs. S. and her husband Mr. Gopal S. are engaged in the business of traditional brass religious statues. They make different types of traditional  idols. They make the idols to meet the demand of their customers. Today, in this area the demand for idols is increasing. To meet this demand they need to invest funds into their business, but due to lack of funds they are unable to meet the demand of their customers. Mrs. S. is requesting a loan for Rs 10000.00 to buy raw materials like wax, silvers, bronzes etc for their business.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her business

loans.name: Rukmani

texts.en:
Rukumani S. is the resident of Bholdhoka. Bholdhoka is located in the Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this area are engaged in small business. There are five members, including herself, in her family. She has two daughters. Her older daughter is studying in grade 3 and younger daughter is in pre-primary school.

Mrs. S. along with her husband Mr. Sahadev S., started a grocery shop, nine years ago in their own house. They sell different types of grocery items in her shop like rice, maize, paddy, noodles and so on.  Now Mrs. S. is requesting a loan for Rs.25000.00 to buy a wider variety of grocery items for her business.She wants to use the increased income to provide better education for her daughters.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Ameena Abdul Ghaffar Group

texts.en:
Ameena baji is a 50 year old married lady and has resided in a city named Arifwala, Pakistan, for the past 30 years. Her husband's name is A. G.. He runs a toy shop and has 6 years experience in the business. She is the mother of three sons. Her elder son has a sweetmeat selling business. The next son is a driver and drives a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Her youngest son reads in kindergarten. Ameena baji works hard to pay for the school fees of her youngest son. She sells milk, which she gets from her buffalo. Presently she has one buffalo but she wants to buy another with the profit of her milk selling business. She is applying for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw for her son. 

She is a group leader with some other women in her locality. Sugran baji wants a loan to change the body of an auto-rickshaw. Sharifan baji wants a loan to buy tools to repair vehicles. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk selling business. Begum baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motoro vehicle)

loans.name: Hem Kumari

texts.en:
Hem Kumari B. lives in Bholdhoka. Bholdhoka is located in the Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this region are engaged in small farming. Mrs. Hem Kumari lives with her husband and three daughters. Her husband Mr. Babul Lal B. is a driver. She has two sons and one daughter. Her older son studies in grade 5, and her younger son and daughter are studying in pre-primary school.

Mrs. Hem Kumari opened her sandal shop five years ago. She sells different styles of sandals for boys and girls. She started her business because she wants to be independent and also wants to help her husband with household expenses. 

To expand her business, she is requesting a loan for Rs 15000.00 to buy different styles of sandals for both boys and girls.

loans.use: To buy different verities of sandals

loans.name: Bina

texts.en: Bina M. is a 40 year old woman and she lives in Thecho, Lalitpur. She lives in a single family with her husband and two sons. Her husband, Mr. Ashok M. works at the public bank. Her older son is studying in grade 6 and her younger son is in primary school. Mrs. M. opened a grocery shop 5 years ago. She sells different grocery goods in her shop. With her first loan from kiva she was able to purchase grocery goods such as rice, maize, snacks, etc for her shop. She opened her shop to improve the economic condition of her family. Now she is requesting a second loan of Rs 30000.00 to increase the necessary stock of food for her shop such as noodles, rice, biscuits and others. She will also use the loan to expand her shop. She wishes to use her profits to give better education to her children.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Kubra Rasheed Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Kubra baji is a 27 year old married lady who has resided in a city named Arifwala, Paksitan, for the past 7 years. Her husband, R. A., runs a Punjabi food business, with 10 years experience. He has a good reputation in the community. She has two daughters. Both of her daughters help her in her clothes sewing business. Kubra baji taught them to sew clothes and now they are independent at sewing. She is applying for a loan to buy material (lentils, cooking oil, flour and spices) to expand the Punjabi food selling business of her husband. 

She is a group leader of some other women of her locality. Bashiran baji wants a loan to buy vehicle wheels to resell. Saleem baji wants a loan to buy animals (goats) for her animal selling business. Salma baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy food items for a Punjabi food business

loans.name: Nirmala

texts.en: Mrs. Nirmala M., 33 years old, lives in Thecho. Thecho is located in the Lalitpur district of Nepal. Thecho is one of the less developed areas of Lalitpur. Most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Mrs.M. lives in a nuclear family with her husband and two sons. Her older son is studying in grade 8 and the younger son is studying in grade 5. Her husband's name is Tari Babu M.. He is a carpenter and opened his furniture-making shop 8 years ago. All the requirements of their family must be met with only the shop’s income. With her first loan from kiva her husband was able to purchase wood supplies for her small furniture shop. Now Mrs. M. is requesting a second loan of Rs 10000.00 to buy timber to be able to fill their orders for furniture. Her husband makes different varieties of furniture such as beds, tables, chairs, and wardrobes

loans.use: To buy timber supplies

loans.name: Razia Ghulam Rasool Group

texts.en:
This is a group loan that consists of three people and Razia baji is the leader. She is a 28 years old married lady and has resided in a city named Arifwala, Pakistan for the past 8 years. Her husband, G. R., is a loader by profession. She has one daughter who is 5 years old. Her brother in law also lives with her, and is involved in a fruit selling business. He has 12 years of  experience in this business. Razia baji stays at home and makes embroided dresses for her neighbors. She shares her income with her husband so that he is able to meet the financial expenses of the household. She is applying for a loan to buy seasonal fruits to expand her brother in law’s fruit selling business. 

Bibi baji and Nasreen baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shop. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits to resell

loans.name: Tavakal

texts.ru:
Косимов Тавакал 1971 года рождения. Он женат, имеет 2 детей. Тавакал занимается торговлей угля, дров, и сельхоз – продуктами. В связи с тяжелым финансовым положением он при помощи знакомых решил начать свой бизнес. На свои сбережения он арендовал маленькое место на базаре в городе Вахдат. Получаемый доход стал основным источником в его семейном бюджете. Закупает он товар в оптовом рынке. Тавакал имеет своих постоянных клиентов. Опыт у него в этой сфере 6 лет.   
Для увеличения товарооборота, то есть покупка угля хочет получить займ в сумме 3000 сомони сроком на 10 месяцев.
texts.en:
Tavakal K. was born in 1971. He is married and has 2 children. He sells coal, firewood and agricultural products. Due to the current difficult financial situation, Tavakal started his business with the help of his friends. He used his savings to rent a small retail space at a market in Vahdat. Now the resulting profit solely provides for his family. Tavakal buys his goods at a wholesale market. He also has consistent customers and a six-year experience in the business. To increase the goods turnover and to buy coal, Tavakal wants to obtain this 10-month $875 loan.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of coal

loans.name: Chini Devi

texts.en:
Mrs. Chini Devi M., 41 years old, lives in Thecho. Thecho is located in Lalitpur district, Nepal. Thecho is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur, and most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Mrs. M. lives in a nuclear family with her husband, one son, and one daughter. Her daughter and son are studying in grades 10 and 9 respectively.

Her husband, Mr. Gopal M., is a plumber. Her husband’s work is the only source of family income. For his work he needs various types of tools and raw materials. She has already cleared her first loan from Kiva. With the help of her Kiva loan, Ms. M. purchased new tools for her husband's work as a plumber. Now Mrs. M. is requesting her second loan of Rs 15,000 to buy modern tools for her husband.

loans.use: To buy tools and equipment

loans.name: Ram Maiya

texts.en:
Mrs. Ram Maiya M. is a resident of Thecho, Lalitpur. The majority of people living in this region are engaged in farming. Mrs. Ram Maiya M. has five members including herself in her family. She has two sons and one daughter. Both her sons are studying in secondary level and her daughter is in pre-primary school.

Her husband's name is Dharma Lal M.. He is a carpenter and opened his furniture shop 3 years ago. All the requirements of the family are fulfilled out of the shop's income. Therefore Mrs. M. is seeking a loan in the amount of Rs10,000 to buy timber to use to build furniture. Her husband makes different varieties of furniture: beds, tables, chairs, wardrobes, and so on.

loans.use: To buy lumber for furniture-making

loans.name: Chandra Bedi

texts.en:
Mrs. Chandra Bedi M. is a 41-year-old woman and she lives in Thecho. She lives in a single family with her husband, a daughter, and a son. Her husband, Mr. Asta M., works as a laborer in housing construction. The income of her family is so low that their life is miserable. They hardly can fulfill their needs. She can't provide good education for her children.

Mrs. M. is a farmer. She has her own land. She grows different vegetables like cauliflower and green vegetables. She sells vegetables in a local market in the morning and in the evening every day. With her first loan from Kiva she was able to purchase the necessary fertilizer and seeds for this year's monsoon growing season. Now she seeks a loan of Rs15, 000 to buy fertilizer and seeds for her work.

Her daughter is now studying in grade 7 and her son is in pre-primary school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Janda Gall Group

texts.en:
Janda Gall is the group leader of the Janda Gall group. There are two members in this group. Each of them would like to receive money for her own business.

Vzra wants to take out a loan for her tailoring business. She wants to buy a new sewing machine for her business. Janda Gall wants to take a loan for her husband’s business. He has a fruit cart. They both want to expand and improve their businesses.

With this loan they can make their businesses larger and support their families and make a better future for themselves and also for their families in the future.

loans.use: to expand their businesses

loans.name: Gun Keshari

texts.en:
Gun Keshari M. lives in a single family with her husband and two sons. She lives in Thecho of Lalitpur district. Thecho is also famous for vegetable farming. Her older son makes traditional idols and her younger son is studying in grade 6. Her husband, Mr. Santa Lal M. is a carpenter.

Mrs. M. opened her tailoring shop 5 years ago. Her specialty is making ladies' dresses. She prefers to make popular dresses like Kurta Sulwar, blouses, ladies' long dresses, Makhshi, and others. Before starting her own business, Mrs. M. took a 4-month training course in tailoring. With her first loan she was able to purchase clothes and equipment for her work.

Now she needs Rs30,000 to buy raw materials for her tailoring work like cloth, thread, and a cutting machine.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her work

loans.name: Ni Luh Juliasih

texts.id: Memelihara babi merupakan pekerjaan sampingan yang memang dijalankan sebagian besar ibu-ibu di desa Perancak. Begitu pula dengan Luh Juliasih yang kesehariannya sebagai ibu rumah tangga juga memelihara babi di rumahnya sudah sejak lama. Hal ini tentu saja untuk menambah penghasilan keluarga disamping tentunya membantu suami di ladang. Penghasilan suaminya yang tidak menentu mengharuskan Luh Juliasih lebih giat lagi beternak babi sehingga kebutuhan keluarga bisa terpenuhi. Setelah mengikuti sosialisasi dari staf DINARI akhirnya Luh Juliasih memutuskan meminjam ke DINARI untuk meningkatkan modal usaha ternak babinya. Pinjaman pertama ini berjumlah Rp.3.750.000,- dengan jangka waktu 6 bulan dan pembayaran kembali akan dilakukan pada akhir periode pinjaman setelah babi dipanen. Untuk mengawali, Luh Juliasih berencana membeli 2 ekor bibit babi penggemukan dengan harga Rp.350.000,- per ekornya. Sedangkan sisa pinjaman akan digunakan untuk cadangan biaya pakan selama enam bulan kedepan. Setelah 5 bulan nanti Luh Juliasih berharap mendapatkan keuntungan Rp.500.000,- dari penjualan babinya termasuk babi yang dibelinya dengan modal sendiri. Hasil dari beternak babi ini memang cukup lumayan bisa memenuhi kebutuhan keluarga dan sekolah anak-anaknya.
texts.en:
Raising pigs are side job that is done by the majority of women in Perancak village. Same with Luh Juliasih who is regularly a housewife who also raised pigs around her house since a long time. This certainly helps the family income, besides helping her husband in the field. Her husband's income is uncertain, and that forced Luh Juliasih to work harder raising pigs, so that family needs could be fulfilled. After attending socialisation from DINARI staff, finally Luh Juliasih decided to borrow from DINARI to increase the capital of her pig farming. First loan was for Rp.3,750,000,- (translator's note: 1US$ fluctuates between Rp 10,000-12,000) for a 6 months period, and payment would be done at period end, after the pigs were sold. To start, Luh Juliasih plans to buy 2 piglets to fatten at Rp.350.000,- per piglet. The rest of the loan would be used as feed expenses for the next six months. After 5 months Luh Juliasih hopes to profit Rp.500,000,- from pig sales, including pigs bought with own funds. Profit from pig farming is sufficient to meet family needs and children schooling.

Translated from Indonesian by Gwan Ang, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pigs and it's feed

loans.name: Dev Maiya

texts.en:
Miss Dev Maiya M. is a 51 year old lady who lives in Thecho village. Thecho is one of the underdeveloped villages of Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. She lives with her father, mother and her brother. Ms.Dev Maiya M. and her brother opened their shop 11 years ago. They sell different types of steel goods such as jugs, plates, water carrying pots, etc. Revenue from the shop is the only source of income for their family. She has already repaid her first loan from kiva. With her first loan she was able to buy additional stock for her store. She sells basic household tools and supplies and has used the funds to increase her stock of plastic and metal ware.
Dev Maiya M. is requesting a loan of Rs 25000 to expand their business and buy necessary items for their shop.

loans.use: To buy a variety of goods for her shop

loans.name: Ni Ketut Sumerti

texts.id: Beternak babi adalah pekerjaan yang sudah ditekuni Ketut Sumerti dari sebelum membina rumah tangga. Karena kebanyakan memang di pedesaan termasuk juga di desa Perancak memelihara babi merupakan kerja sampingan para ibu-ibu rumah tangga disamping mengolah ladang. Karena kebutuhan ekonomi dalam keluarga semakin besar dan suaminya yang sebagai petani juga penghasilannya tidak menentu maka Ketut Sumerti melihat peluang bekerja sama dengan DINARI adalah sesuatu yang sangat bagus dan membantunya dalam meningkatkan penghasilan dari beternak babinya. Ketut memutuskan untuk menambah modal usahanya dengan meminjam ke DINARI sebesar Rp.3.750.000,- dengan jangka waktu 6 bulan dan pembayaran dilakukan sekaligus pada akhir periode pinjaman dimana babi-babi peliharaan sudah dapat dipanen. Ketut merencanakan membeli 2 ekor bibit babi penggemukan untuk dipelihara disamping babi-babi yang sudah ada di kandangnya. Sisa pinjaman akan digunakan untuk biaya pakan selama 6 bulan masa pemeliharaan. Untuk mengawali memang cukup sulit karena diharapkan babi-babi peliharaannya semuanya harus panen bagus tetapi dengan pendampingan dari para staf DINARI tentang cara memelihara babi yang baik maka Ketut berharap keuntungan yang akan didapat mencapai sekitar Rp.500.000,-. Tentunya hasil ini sangat membantu keluarga nantinya. Terutama untuk kebutuhan anak-anaknya.
texts.en:
Raising pigs has been work for Ketut Sumerti before she started her household. In many villages, including Perancak, raising pigs are side jobs for housewifes besides field work. Since family economy needs are greater, and her tenant farmer's husband income is uncertain, so Ketut Sumerti saw an opportunity to work together with DINARI as a good way to help increase her pig farming income. Ketut decided to increase her capital by borrowing from DINARI for Rp.3,750,000,- (Translator’s note: 1 US$ fluctuates between Rp10,000-12,000.00) for a period of 6 months, and payment at period end after the farmed pigs are harvested. Ketut plans to buy 2 piglets for fattening to be raised together with other pigs already in her stall. Rest of the loan will be used to buy pig feeds for the 6 months raising. To start is difficult since it was expected that the raised pigs have all to harvested well, but with DINARI staff training on how to raise pigs well, Ketut hopes that profit received could be about Rp.500,000,-. This result would help her family, especially childrens needs.

Translated from Indonesian by Gwan Ang, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pigs and it's feed

loans.name: Ni Luh Eka

texts.id: Semakin mendesaknya biaya hidup dari hari ke hari membuat Luh Eka tidak bisa hanya mengandalkan hasil dari mengolah ladang bersama suaminya. Luh Eka mencoba untuk lebih meningkatkan hasil dari beternak babi yang sudah menjadi kerja selingan pada waktu pagi dan sore hari. Tetapi melihat hasil dari beternak babi cukup lumayan maka Luh Eka memutuskan untuk menambah populasi ternak babinya dengan meminjam modal ke DINARI sebesar Rp.3.750.000,- dengan jangka waktu pinjaman selama 6 bulan dan pelunasan akan dilakukan pada akhir periode pinjaman setelah babi terjual. Kedepan setelah menerima pinjaman ini rencananya akan dibelikan bibit babi penggemukan sebanyak 2 ekor dulu disamping sekarang di rumahnya juga sudah ada babi-babi dari modal sendiri yang dipelihara. Harga bibit per ekor berkisar Rp.350.000,- dan sisa pinjaman nanti akan digunakan untuk biaya pakan babi selama 6 bulan pemeliharaan. Luh Eka berharap bisa mendapat keuntungan mencapai Rp.500.000,-. Hasil pelihara babi ini diharapkan bisa meningkatkan penghasilan keluarganya dan mampu membiayai anaknya yang masih kecil.
texts.en:
Increased pressures from day to day living expenses, made Luh Eka could not depend on field farming with her husband. Luh Eka tried to increase results from pig farming which is already her side job mornings and evenings. But seeing results from pig raising is quite good, Luh Eka decided to increase her pig populations by borrowing capital from DINARI for Rp.3,750,000,- (Translator’s note: 1 US$ fluctuates between Rp10,000-12,000.00) for a period of 6 months, and payment at period end after the pigs are sold. When loan is received the plan was to buy 2 piglets for fattening, besides the other pigs she already raised from her own capital. Price per piglet is Rp.350,000,- and rest of the loan would be used for feed expenses for the 6 months raising period. Luh Eka hopes profit could reach Rp.500,000,-. Result from pig raising is hoped to increase family's income, and to pay for child expenses, who is still small.

Translated from Indonesian by Gwan Ang, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: pigs and it's feed

loans.name: Gita

texts.en:
Mrs. Gita S. is 42 years old and lives in Kritipur, Kathmandu, Nepal. Kritipur is one of the beautiful, but under developed villages of Nepal. Most of the people of this region are poor and dependent on agriculture alone. 
Mrs. S. has two sons. Her eldest son studies for his BBS (Bachelor in Business Study) and her youngest son is in grade 10. Her husband, Mr. Birendra S. is an office worker.

Mrs. S. opened a grocery shop 9 years ago She sells different types of grocery items such as rice, maize, pulse, biscuits, noodles. Her sons also help her with her work. The demand for grocery products is increasing in this area, so she is requesting a loan for Rs 30000.00 to buy grocery products to meet the demand. She spends the major part of her income to provide a good education for her sons.

loans.use: To increase her supply of grocery products

loans.name: Ni Made Sarmi

texts.id: Ni Made Sarmi tergolong ibu rumah tangga yang sangat ulet dalam bekerja membantu suaminya. Tahu bahwa suaminya yang sebagai petani memiliki penghasilan yang pas-pasan untuk membiayai keluarga maka Made Sarmi menekuni usaha babi lebih giat lagi melihat hasilnya juga cukup besar. Dengan kandang yang cukup memadai di belakang rumahnya, Made Sarmi meningkatkan modal usahanya dengan meminjam ke DINARI lewat program kelompok peternak babi dengan besar pinjaman Rp.3.750.000,- dalam waktu pinjaman selama 6 bulan serta pelunasan dilakukan pada akhir periode pinjaman setelah panen. Made sudah memutuskan untuk memperbanyak peliharaan babinya dengan membeli 2 ekor lagi dengan harga per ekor Rp.300.000,-. Sebelumnya dengan modal sendiri Made Sarmi juga sudah mempunyai beberapa ekor babi di kandangnya. Setelah 5 bulan pemeliharaan diharapkan babi sudah terjual dan keuntungan yang didapat berkisar Rp.500.000,-. Pinjaman ini juga digunakan untuk biaya pakan selama 6 bulan pemeliharaan babinya. Made Sarmi merasa hasil usaha babinya sangat membantu dalam memenuhi kebutuhan keluarga terutama biaya hidup anak-anaknya. Program DINARI ini dirasakan sangat menolong ibu-ibu di pedesaan seperti Made Sarmi dalam meningkatkan hasil beternak babi.
texts.en:
Ni Made Sarmi is considered a housewife who is persistent in her work to help her husband. Knowing that as a tenant farmer her husband's income is just enough to meet family expenses, has made Made Sarmi to run her pig business harder, especially after seeing that the results were quite good. With a stall that is sufficient behind her house, Made Sarmi increased her business capital by borrowing to DINARI via pig's farmer group for a loan of Rp.3,750,000,- (Translator’s note: 1 US$ fluctuates between Rp10,000-12,000.00) for a loan period of 6 months that will be repaid at period end after harvest. Made decides to increase her pigs by buying 2 more for Rp.300,000,-/each. Previously, from own capital, Made Sarmi already own few pigs in her stall. After 5 months raising, it was hoped that the pigs could be sold for a profit of about Rp.500.000,-. This loan is also used for its feed expenses for 6 months raising the pigs. Made Sarmi feels that the pig farming has helped in fulfilling family expense needs, especially childrens living expenses. Program DINARI is felt as very much helping village ladies like Made Sarmi in increasing results from pig farming.

Translated from Indonesian by Gwan Ang, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pig and it's feed

loans.name: Sunita

texts.en:
Mrs. Sunita R. lives in Sanepa. Sanepa is located in Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this area are engaged in small businesses like grocery stores, small hotels, and stationery stores.

Mrs. R. lives in a single family with her husband. Both husband and wife are engaged in their own small restaurant, which they opened 3 years ago. They sell different types of food items in her shop, especially Nepali food. They also sell tea and coffee. Now, Mrs. R. is requesting a loan to expand her business by purchasing necessary food products.

loans.use: To buy food materials for her work.

loans.name: Sanumaiya

texts.en:
Mrs. Sanumaiya K. is a tailor in the town of  Balkhu. She opened her tailoring shop 10 years ago. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies dresses like the Kurta Sulwar, which is very popular with Nepali women. Before starting her own business, Mrs. K. took a 6 month training course in tailoring from a tailor shop near her locality.

She is requesting a loan to buy materials for her tailoring work. She wants to add to her family's income and support her children's education.

She has one son and three daughters, who are all studying. Her husband, Mr. Rati Ram K., works in an office.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her work.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane O. is a volunteer member of the Schobac group in Siaya, Kenya. The group has received training from K-MET on home based care patient services and is also part of the K-MET microfinance program.

She owns a tailoring shop in Sagam Siaya, Kenya. Her shop is in her home, which she opened in 1983. She makes dresses for men, women and children, which she sells to various market places. She is able to generate Kshs 8000 in profits. Besides tailoring, she grows crops such as maize and beans. Currently, she has over 20 bags of maize which she intends to sell when prices go up. 

Jane has applied for a loan to add more stock of tailoring materials and invest the remaining amount in her farm. 

Jane is married to a retired prison warden officer. They have 5 children, all of whom have finished school, though some are still dependents because they are attending college.

loans.use: To buy tailoring materials and invest the remaining in her farm.

loans.name: Bandhira

texts.en:
Mrs. Bandhira K., 45 years old, is a tailor in the town of Balkhu in Kathmandu.  She opened her tailoring shop 7 years ago. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies dresses and school uniforms for both boys and girls. She prefers to make popular dresses like Kurta Sulwar, blouses, ladies' long dresses, Makhshi, and others.
 
Before starting her own business, Mrs. K. took a 6 month training course in tailoring when she was younger. Now she is requesting a loan to buy raw materials for her tailoring work.

Her husband's name is Rabindra K. and he works in a private office. She has two sons who are both studying in BBS (Bachelors in Business Study) Level.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her work.

loans.name: Elizabeth Adhiambo

texts.en:
Elizabeth Adhiambo A. rents a workshop in the Likoni area of Mombasa, Kenya where she has a woodworking business. Elizabeth buys timber from local shops to make chapatti boards for rolling chapatti (a local flat bread), chopping boards, mug hanging stands, bottle openers, and mortar and pestles. She started this business in 1997 so that she could pay for her children’s school fees. 

Elizabeth takes large orders from local supermarkets, as well as supplying smaller shops. From large supermarket orders, Elizabeth might make a 7,000 KSH profit from each order – she receives about 2 orders of this kind a month, as well as smaller orders from the small shops. 

Elizabeth has applied for a loan in order to buy more timber and a blade for carving the wood.

Elizabeth is married with 7 dependent children. She dreams of building her own house, so that she and her family no longer have to rent living space above her current workshop.

loans.use: To purchase timber and a carving blade.

loans.name: Education Group

texts.en:
A. Ghafor is the group leader of the Education Group. There are four members in this group. All of them want to receive a loan for their businesses

A. Shakab and A. Ghafor want to take out a loan for their general stores. They want to make their businesses larger. Zayalah also wants to take out a loan for his general store.They want to buy necessary materials for their shops.  M. Omar also wants to take a loan for his general store, to complete his stock. They are requesting a loan of 20000 Afghani for a term of 7 months. 

They want to say this loan is very useful, because this loan can provide a good chance for poor entrepreneurs to expand their business

loans.use: to expand and improve their businesses

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica O. owns two businesses at Sinaga village, Siaya. She buys jaggery (product used in making local brews)in bulk and then sells it to the local brewers. She purchases her product from the sugar manufacturing companies. Her business has flourished over the last 7 years due to high demand for the product.

She also buys cereals, especially maize, in bulk during harvesting season and sells it to her clients when prices are high, thus ensuring a considerable profit.

Monica has applied for a loan to buy more cereals.

She is married with 8 dependent children. Her husband is a retired local leader and is currently farming.

loans.use: To purchase stock of cereals in bulk.

loans.name: Run

texts.en:
Run S. K., 38, is married and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She grows and sells various kinds of vegetables at the market and is able to make US$6.00 every day in revenue. She grows vegetables on a plot of land at her home.

Her husband is a fisherman. He sells his catch to the market, and also provides some for the family. On average, he makes US$10.00 a day in revenue. This couple has two school-aged children. Mrs. Run is asking for a loan of US$600 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to transport fish to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Chin

texts.en:
Chin K. C. is 35 years old and sells sugar cane juice from her home and makes US$3.70 a day. She lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. Her husband is a local teacher, earning about US$2.00 a day. This couple has three school-aged children.

Mrs. Chin K. C. is asking for a loan to build a stand, and increase her sales of sugar cane juice.

loans.use: To build a stand to sell sugar cane juice.

loans.name: Choun

texts.en: Choun K. S., 37, is married and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works in a grocery store and makes US$4.00 a day. Her husband, Leng Loung, has a business as a taxi driver and eventually makes about US$10.00 every day. Mrs. Choun K. S. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to expand her grocery store by adding more products to attract her clients.

loans.use: To expand her grocery store.

loans.name: Nem

texts.en: Nem C. L. is 28 years old and lives with her husband in the province of Kampong Cham in Cambodia. She is a true entrepreneur who operates a grocery store in a busy market to earn a living. She is able to make around US$2.50 every day, while her husband works as a customs officer and makes US$6.00 a day. This couple has one school-aged child. Mrs. Nem C. L. is asking for a loan to add to her grocery inventory to meet her clients' demands.

loans.use: To add to her grocery inventory.

loans.name: Ann

texts.en: Ann S., 33, is married and resides in Kampong Cham with her husband, pictured here. She and her husband are corn sellers and are able to make US$ 5 a day. This couple has a motorbike which attaches to a  trailer to transport corn to sell. Mrs. Ann S. is asking for a loan to purchase another motorbike and trailer. The purchase will allow her to increase the amount of corn they are able to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and trailer

loans.name: Chhay

texts.en: Chhay S. is 38 years old and lives in Kampong Cham province with her husband. She operates a grocery business and is able to make US$ 20 every day in revenue. Her husband, Ros Samart, 45, is a policeman, earning around US$ 3 a day. This couple has four children, one of whom is a policeman while three are students. Mrs. Chhay S. is asking for a loan to rent a yam farm to collect yams for sale.

loans.use: To rent a yam farm to collect yams for sale

loans.name: Chheam

texts.en: Chheam S., 37, lives in Kandal Province in Cambodia. He currently works for a rubber factory. He gets a salary of $90 per month. He is married to Pen Sreymong, 32, who is a good mother of two children; both of them are teenagers and go to school. She is employed as a worker for fish raising and gets a salary of $75 a month. Mr. S. and his wife hope to have a suitable investment out of their home. Therefore, they both are applying for a loan as capital to purchase piglets to raise. The loan will help them to earn additional income to sustain their family's food sufficiently.

loans.use: to purchase piglets to raise

loans.name: Zubaydullo

texts.ru:
Содиков Зубайдулло Махмадалиевич - преуспевающий предприниматель. Ему  33 года  и у него 4 детей. Два года назад он начал свое дело в сфере животноводства. Он откармливает скот и продает. Он живет со своей семьей в селе Ромит. Зубайдулло каждый день работает очень усердно, чтобы обеспечить семью. Он просыпается рано утром, чистит навес, и пастбища. 
Зубайдулло берет заем для покупки быка. Он хочет, держат быка четыре месяца на откорме. За это время бык наберет в весе и соответственно подорожает. Первые четыре месяца для него будет льготным периодом. И в эти месяцы он будет платить только проценты за кредит. Начиная с пятого месяца, Зубайдулло будет платить основную сумму и процент. Хочет получить займ в сумме 3000 сомони сроком на 8 месяцев.
texts.en:
Zubaydullo Mahmadalievich S. is a successful businessman. He is 33 years old and has four children. Two years ago he started his own business in the field of animal husbandry. He feeds and breeds cattle and then resells it. He lives with his family in the village of Romit. Zubaydullo works very hard every day to support his family.

He wakes up early in the morning to clean in the pastures. Zubaydullo wants to get a loan to buy a bull. He wants to keep the bull for four months for growth. During this time the bull will gain weight and will cost more. The first four months will be his grace period. During these months he will be paying off only the interest of this loan. Starting with fifth month Zubaydullo will start paying the principle balance and interest. He wants to take out a loan for 3000 somoni (USD$875) for an 8 months term.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a bull

loans.name: Chhuon

texts.en: Chhuon T. is 61 years old and a resident of Kandal Province, Cambodia. She is widowed and earns a living by selling Khmer traditional medicine. The medicine is made from root trees. She normally buys the root from the people who carved from the forest and then she makes the medicine them and sells it to patients. She can earn an average of $4 per day, and she has been in the business more than four years. T. has three children; two of them are married and the other one is single. To help a little with the family's expenses, one her single child is working as a garment worker. To earn additional income, T. requests a loan to use as capital to buy more various kinds of root to make the medicine for sell.

loans.use: to buy more raw materials to make the medicine

loans.name: Ray's Group

texts.en:
This small loan is being requested by three borrowers, all of whom live in Sarika Keo Commune in Kandal Province, Cambodia. The group leader, Mrs. Ray S., was born in 1959 and is a widow. She has four children: two are single and the other two are married. Three of her children are employed—two of them are fisherman and one is a farmer—and earn money to help meet with the family's living expenses. Since 1985, S. has run a business selling fish , and is currently earning an average of $3 each day. Because fish-selling is the main way for her to earn money, S. is applying for a loan to purchase additional fish to sell, and the remaining loan will be used to do rice farming. The other two borrowers are:
San S., 32, who is a vegetable seller and a widow. She needs a loan to buy a variety of vegetables to sell.
Um S., age 28, sells coffee from home, and she is applying for a loan to purchase a pump.

loans.use: to purchase additional fishes for sale

loans.name: Amina Ahmed

texts.en:
Amina Ahmed H. is a 53-year-old widow living in the Likoni neighborhood in Mombasa, Kenya. Amina runs two businesses and also works on the city council in town.

Amina has a business selling fruit-flavored popsicles, which she started 10 years ago. She has two employees who come to her home each morning to receive a supply of popsicles that they take to town and sell on the streets. Her second business is one selling building materials, like stones and “sarugi” tiles, which she started 2 years ago. Building goes by season in Kenya, so Amina does not sell much during the rainy season, but is quite busy now during the dry season, as people are building homes and offices before the rains come.

Amina found that working on the council has not provided her with a high enough salary to support the 5 out of her 10 children who are still dependent on her. Her profits from the popsicle business go toward daily transport, meals, and daily costs, while the larger (but infrequent) sales of building materials provide money for school fees and larger purchases.

Amina has applied for a loan of approximately 375 USD in order to buy what will be her second freezer, flavor and sugar packets, food coloring, and ice cream powder, as well as building materials. Amina says that she is two years away from retirement from the council, but cannot leave her businesses until her children are older. She has 1 child in university, 2 in college, 1 in form 3, and 1 in standard 7. They all attend private schools and the fees are high. Amina would like to expand from selling building materials into building houses with those materials and selling them. She is currently working to save funds in order to advance with this plan.

loans.use: Increase her stock

loans.name: Asanta

texts.en:
Asanta L. is currently in the business of making local brew and is requesting a loan to open up a shop. Asanta is 25 years old and is married to a husband who is an air traffic officer. She has one child and her child does not go to school yet.

With the extra profits from her loan, Asanta hopes to be able to expand the business. BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: expand her business

loans.name: Reat

texts.en: Mr. S. is 30 years old and grows vegetable crops to sell. He lives in Siem Reap Province. He is married to Mrs. Khorn and has two children. He works growing vegetables to sell with his wife, and started his business in 1998 and can earn around $2.17 per day. This business is supporting his family's living. It has gone well, and he sells to his regular customers who come to buy at his house. Now, his crop is growing but it is being damaged by insects. Hence, he would like to ask for a loan to purchase insecticide to protect his vegetable crop.

loans.use: to purchase insecticide to protect his vegetable crop

loans.name: Diep

texts.en: Diep H., 36, lives in the province of Banteay Meanchey, Cambodia, where she owns and runs a plot of land next to her house growing vegetable crops. She can plant her crops twice a year, and she was taught this by her grandfather. She is currently a good mother of five children. All of them are single and still live in the family home. She is married to Srey Thoun, age 38, who is a local horse-cart driver. He also buys oxen from far-away places to raise and re-sell for a profit. Because oxen-selling is a very important business for earing money, Thoun and his wife would like to ask for a loan to buy extra oxen to raise and sell.

loans.use: to buy extra oxen to raise and sell

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica S. is currently in the business of making local brew and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Monica is 30 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Poung

texts.en: Poung T., 39, is a local palm tree climber. With the palm tree climbing, he can tap palm juice from palm trees, boil it to make palm sugar or turn it into palm wine for sale. He is currently earning an average of US$11 a day to help feed his family. His wife's name is Leap Heng, and she is is a good housewife. She cooks delicious meals for the family and is the good mother of three children; all of them are teenagers and still under her care. T. and Heng are facing difficulties with their living conditions; their house is not so good and small for them. Thus they have decided to ask for a loan to purchase wood to repair their old house.

loans.use: to purchase wood to repair their old house

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is currently in the business of selling fresh fish at the market and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Susan is 28 years old and is married to a husband who is a soldier. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Teav

texts.en: Mr. Teav V., age 38, is a commune committee clerk; his wife's name is Yen Chancy, and she is aged 31. She currently runs a little store in front of her house and sells vegetables and some groceries to the villagers. She normally sells her items from a seller at the market. She started in this business a long time ago. Chancy currently takes care of three children, all of whom are teenagers and also attend school. Recently, she sold all her items from her store. She talked with her husband, and they have decided to ask for a loan to purchase a range of groceries and more vegetables to sell. The family lives in Kompong Tom Province. (V.'s wife appears in the picture because he was not available)

loans.use: to purchase a range of groceries and more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Karmela

texts.en:
Karmela B. is currently in the business of selling beans, flour and sorghum at the market and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Carmela is 45 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: pay school fees for children

loans.name: Perlinda

texts.en:
32 year-old Mrs. Perlinda C. is a resident of GK Village-Bongbong, Ozamiz City.  She is married to Mr. Fedelito C. and is blessed with two children; a girl of 6 years old in kindergarten 2 and a boy of 3 years old in kindergarten 1. 

	Early in 1990, she decided to go to Manila to find a job.  In 1994, she decided to resign from her job and started to establish a sari-sari store out of her savings.  She got married in 1997 to Mr. Fedelito C., a construction worker.  Early 2008, the couple decided to go to Ozamiz city due to the economic situation in Manila. Upon her arrival in Ozamiz City, her elder brother gave her a small amount of initial capital for her business to support her family.  The sister of her husband also gave the opportunity to her husband to drive their motor cab to generate income for the household.  She started up a sari-sari store in her residence with the money given to her by her brother.  She buys grocery items and also engages in E-Load business.

	When she heard that Paglaum MPC was expanding its membership in their barangay, she decided to join in order to have additional capital for her sari-sari store and also to be able to have savings deposit and insurances for her family.  She produced her 1st cycle in Paglaum MPC last July 2008 in the amount of P 7,000.00 as additional capital for her business and also engage in food vending to be sold in her neighbors.  A portion of the proceeds was used in the repacking chlorine and tawas to be delivered to the public market and to different grocery stores in the city.  Unfortunately, an emergency befell her family; that’s why she defaulted in her weekly payment.  However, despite of what happened she will find other sources and able to recover all her losses.  “That was a lesson to learn, if I have enough savings maybe my capital shall not be diverted to use for emergencies.” she said.  Now she availed her 2nd loan in the amount of P 4,000.00 for additional capital of her existing business. 

	  She’s hoping that that someday she will able to expand her business, especially for repacking chlorine and tawas for the whole province in Misamis Occidental, but also in the nearby provinces.  She dreams that in time her daughter will become a nurse and her son will become a policeman.

loans.use: additional capital for sari-sari and food vending

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana L. is a village store owner at Barangay, Antagan 2nd, Tumauini, Isabela.
