She is married to Guillermo and they have three children: Rose-Ana, 18, and Divine Grace, 13, are high school students while Jesrael, 11, is graduating from elementary school. Susana hopes to support her children’s education so that they will be able to earn a college degree.  

Susana has been running her store for three years now. She now wants to improve her store; to do this, she would like to borrow PHP 6,000 (150 USD). She will use the loan to purchase more inventory, such as kitchen commodities, toiletries, soft drinks and more. This loan will be of great help in expanding her store. She is also planning to save some money for their farming needs.  

She hopes to sustain her business so that she will able to provide her family’s daily needs, send her children to school and have a better family life.  Susana believes that a person who is hard-working will harvest the fruit of her sacrifices in the end, and this keeps her motivated while managing her business.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is married to her loving and responsible husband Editho; together they have two children: 14-year-old John Glenn, in high school, and 11-year-old Dennis Mark, in elementary school. Teresita's husband's farm is their family's main source of income, providing for their immediate needs and supporting the education for the children.

Teresita helps supplement this income through her village store, which she started four years ago. Along with selling basic commodities in their neighborhood, she also ventured into the direct selling business of different products such as NATASHA, AVON, BOARD WALK and MSE. She is now applying for a loan of PHP 8000 (175 USD) to improve her business.

Teresita believes that she can achieve her dreams little by little by working hard. Together, she and her husband face the future with confidence.

loans.use: Additional capital to improve her business

loans.name: But

texts.en: But N., 43, lives in Pursat Province, Cambodia. She earns a living as a local cultivator, as well as raising pigs for additional income. She has been earning an average of $3 per day since 1983. She is married and has five children—three of them are married and two are single and in school—while her husband is working with her in the business. N. is running her business very well with her pig raising, which she can raise at least twice a year. Because pigs are the main way for her to earn income and to expand her business, she is applying for a loan to buy more piglets to raise.

loans.use: to buy more piglets to raise

loans.name: Rubelyn

texts.en:
Rubelyn I. is a very diligent woman. With a small savings, Rubelyn invested in a small vending business which she hopes to become a village store some day. She never loses hope in looking for opportunities which could help her business, especially when there is a micro-finance institution that can support her financing needs. 

Although Rubelyn's family has other sources of income, such as her husband's farm and their piggery, Rubelyn would like to continue to expand her business because she would really like to have her own store some day. To do this, she is applying for a loan of PHP 4000 (100 USD) to buy more inventory.

Rubelyn and her husband Reynaldo have four children:  Lorilyn, 16, and Erwin, 15, are in high school; Rejeallaine, 8, is in elementary school; and five-year-old Renalyn. Rubelyn and her husband are hoping that they can provide good education for their children.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Josphine

texts.en:
Josphine L. is currently in the business of selling beer at a bar and is requesting a loan to expand the bar. Josphina is 46 years old and is married to a husband who is a nurse at the hospital. She has 7 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: pay school  fees for her children

loans.name: Liv

texts.en: Liv P. is a tailor and works from her house in Kandal Province, Cambodia. She earns around $0.5 per day. She is widowed and has two children—one is married and lives in the family's home—and one nephew and sister are also living with her family. One single son is studying in university and also is employed as cashier for a club in Phnom Penh city, and he can help to reduce the family's expenses. Because she faces difficulties paying for transportation, to reduce costs, Liv would like to ask for a loan to buy a second-hand motorcycle for her son go to work. Also, her son can earn income from the motorcycle by driving a taxi sometimes. For the remaining amount of the loan, she uses it to purchase wood to repair her old house. She said the loan will help to improve her family's income and living conditions. Her son is shown in the photo because she was not available for photographing.

loans.use: to buy a second hand motorcycle for her son go to work

loans.name: Jama Khan

texts.en:
Jama Khan lives in district 17 of Kabul, Afghanistan; he is married with three children and he is a wood seller. He needs a small loan for his brother’s business because he is new in this business. 

He has requested an individual loan of 42000 Afghani for a term of 17 months; he wants to make his business larger and expand it. Also, he wants to complete the inventory of his business and buy necessary materials for his shop.

Jama Khan is really happy with this process of small loans in Afghanistan. He wants to thank all Kiva lenders and AFSG in Afghanistan.

loans.use: complete the inventory of his business and buy necessary materials

loans.name: Seang

texts.en: Seang P., 39, started her business a long time ago. She is a grocery seller. She sells items like cooked ingredients, sweets, and canned goods. She has been running her business out of her home, and currently earns an income of approximately $4 a day. She now lives in Kandal Province, Cambodia, where she cares for two children; both of them are teenagers and attend school. She is married to Touch Thy, 36, who is a civil servant. P. would like to ask for a loan to add to her savings to  purchase a plot of farmland, and the remaining loan will be use to buy a range of groceries for sale.

loans.use: to purchase a plot of land

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
Georgina A. is 29 years old and is married with two children. Currently, one is schooling and the last born is still breastfeeding. She lives with her family in Kumasi. According to Georgina, she works very hard to support her husband in taking care of the home. She lives in her husband's family's house with the kids. She says the family members of her husband put pressure on her to work as if she is a servant to them. She has thought of renting a house but she is constrained by lack of funds to run her business, never mind talk of money to rent a single room. She is now confused about what to do because everything boils down to funds.

Georgina sells household products such as cooking utensils, plastic bowls, buckets and plates. She makes her sales by ‘hawking’, which is door-to-door sales in the community. Georgina is an achiever and her focus is on saving enough to see her kids through school. She wants to use the loan to buy increased stocks of plastic materials and kitchen sets to serve her customers. She believes with that she can save enough to rent a single room. She would be very grateful for your support. She hopes to receive GHS 500 to make her business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her save more to take care of her household.

loans.use: To buy increased stocks of plastic materials and kitchen sets

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Managing a village store has become a daily routine for Rowena.  The business is doing well and is being managed well; however, there are still many things Rowena and her husband would like to do to further improve their business.  

Rowena is now requesting a loan of PHP 5000 (125 USD) which will greatly aid in the improvement of her business, allowing her to purchase additional inventory and merchandise. The store renovations will be set aside for the future. She wants to invest her money in her store and then save for the future needs of their family.  

Rowena I. is 23 years old and married to Rommel, her business partner.  The couple has a two-year-old daughter named Trisha Mae and they are living in Yeban Sur, Benito Soliven, Isabela with their parents and some relatives.  Rowena is happy that, despite being a young couple, they are able to handle their responsibilities well as being parents to Trisha.

loans.use: Purchase inventory.

loans.name: Mely

texts.en:
Mely M., 53, is married to Melchor, a farmer. Their marriage has been blessed with four children: Ferdinand, 29, Janeth, 25, George, 23, and Darwin, 21. All of them were unable to graduate from high school due to lack of financial resources. Today, Mely and her husband live in their house alone, as all their children are busy with their own jobs.  

Mely has been running a simple store in their village since 2003. She is currently asking for a PHP 6000 (150 USD) loan in order to increase the variety products that she sells in her store and to support their farming needs. She has said that she must work double duty in order to assist her husband in their farm so that they can always provide for the needs of their family.  Mely always prays to God to give them good health, especially now as they are getting older.

loans.use: Purchase inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchasing a motorcycle to use to transport passengers

loans.name: Lorence

texts.en:
With her sacrifices and hard work, Lorence deserves to be called one of the empowered women of her generation.  Lorence G. is 34 years old and separated from her husband, taking sole responsibility for their three children: Angel, 11, Le-ann, 4, and Lugirich, 2. She and her children live together happily in Antagan 2nd of Tumauini, Isabela.  

At present, Lorence is striving hard to provide a better life for her children.  She operates a vending business selling homemade native snacks made from glutinous rice and sugar.  She sells her products to her regular customers in the village and earns an average income of PHP 4000 a month.  She has been in this business for three years now and she hopes to maintain it for the future of her family.  In order to do this, she would like to request a loan of PHP 6000 (150 USD) so that she can buy more ingredients for her products and be able to increase her sales. 

Lorence dreams of sending all her children to school and finishing their studies. When that time comes, she will be proud that she made it by herself.  She believes that two heads are better than one, but since she is already separated, she promised to herself that she will be both a good mother AND father to her three children. She is willing to sacrifice for their sake and she also knows that her faith in God will guide her.

loans.use: Buy more ingredients for her homemade native snacks

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros operates a small store which offers different commodities to her fellow villagers. She is pleased to be able to generate an average income of PHP 700 a week, which supports the education of her children. She dreams of improving her business so she can provide a better life to her family and send her children to school.  

She is applying for a loan of PHP 5000 (125 USD) which she will use to increase her inventory so she can earn more income. 

Milagros is 40 years old and married to Arturo, a farmer.  They have five children: Arman, 27; Arnel, 26; Marisol, 22 and a college graduate; Jayson, 20 and a college student; and AmyJane, 10 and in elementary school. Having a family that helps one another in achieving a better life makes Milagros happy and proud.

loans.use: Purchase inventory

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes G. is 51 years old and lives in the village of Antagan 2nd, Tumauini, Isabela. Her husband, Eduardo, serves as a Barangay Councilor and also works as a farmer. They have four children: 32-year-old Romel, a high school graduate; 27-year-old Elmer, an elementary school graduate; 24-year-old Emerson, a high school graduate; and 22-year-old Edimer, a college graduate. Three of their children are already married and the youngest is now working. 

Mercedes has run a sari-sari store (a community based store) for almost a year now. The income from her store supports the basic needs of their family and serves as a rolling capital for her business. She is applying for a loan of PHP 5000 (125 USD) which will be used to purchase basic in-demand commodities, such as soaps, soft drinks and rice. She hopes that her business will improve because it has also helped them in their farming needs. Her dream of improving her business is her motivation to work hard and live a simple life.

loans.use: Purchase inventory

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa A. and her husband, Larry, live in Barangay Antagan, Tumauini, Isabela, along with their three children: Laymar, 11, Larry Jr., 5, and Larrysa, 4. One of Marissa's dreams is to send her children to school and hopefully finish their education, for she believes it is the only treasure that she can give to them.  

For two years, Marissa has ventured into the vegetable vending business; she keeps on going to support the needs of her family. In keeping with her dream to see her business grow, she is applying for a loan of PHP 5000 (125 USD) which will enable her to buy more vegetables to sell (in addition to the vegetables she harvests from their backyard).  Aside from vegetables, she also sells snacks, as requested by her customers.  

She promises to work hard so that, in her simple ways, she can help her husband in earning a living.

loans.use: Purchase vegetables to re-sell

loans.name: Aida

texts.fr: Aida N., 33 ans mariée, 11 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Mbirdiam à Thiès. Elle veut acheter de la marchandise (céréales, légumes, poissons séchés et poissons fumés)  pour renforcer son commerce. Les revenus tirés de son commerce lui permettent d’améliorer le bien être et la santé  de ses enfants.  Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.
texts.en:
Aida N., age 33, is married and has eleven children to look after. She is a member of the village council of Mbirdiam in Thiès. Aida wants to buy merchandise (grain, vegetables, dried and smoked fish) to boost her commerce. The income derived from her commerce enables her to improve the well-being and health of her children. She is requesting a loan that will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell grain, vegetables, dried fish, and smoked fish

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua A. is a 35-year-old entrepreneur. She is married with five children who are currently attending school through the help of government free compulsory education. It is her daily dream to continue to provide quality education for her children to give them better future life.

She lives at their family house in Apatrapa in Kumasi. Within the community there are diverse business activities and most of them are petty traders. Akua owns and operates a little grocery shop with items like rice, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, assorted biscuits, candies, evaporated milk, etc.

She wants to use the loan to buy cartons of evaporated milk, bags of rice, canned foods and drinks, and cooking oil to increase her stock of goods. With increased stocks of different varieties, she hopes to make more income to provide for the educational needs of her children. She hopes to repay the loan in due time because she believes the loan would boost her business growth. Akua belongs to a village bank called ‘Nyame naye’ which means "God did it". She hopes to receive GHS 500 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her save more to take care of the household.

loans.use: To buy cartons of evaporated milk, bags of rice, canned foods and drinks, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: François-Xavier G.

texts.fr: Né le 07 Décembre 1983 à Zassa ; un village de la ville historique d’Abomey dans le Département du Zou, monsieur H. G. François Xavier est originaire de l’OUEME, un autre Département du Bénin. Père de deux enfants tous scolarisés au cours primaire, il s’est marié avec LOKOSSOU Alice Yédmon une ménagère. Le monsieur à un kiosque dans le grand marché international du BENIN (TOKPA) où il gère trois cabines téléphoniques. Il vend aussi des cartes de recharges téléphoniques. Il mène cette activité depuis 2 ans. Il est à son premier crédit pour renforcer son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. François Xavier G. H. was born on December 7, 1983 in Zassa; a village in the historical town of Abomey in the department of Zou. He is originally from Oueme, another department of Benin. He is the father of two children, all attending primary school. He is married to Alice Yédmon LOKOSSOU, a homemaker. This gentleman has a kiosk at the large international market of Benin (TOKPA) where he manages three phone booths. He also sells phone cards. He has been in the business for two years. This is his first loan to strengthen his activity.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of phone cards

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa S. is married and the mother of four children. Currently they all attend school. She is a 38-year-old energetic businesswoman who sells foodstuffs like cooking oil, bags of rice, canned beef, canned fish, etc. With her four years of experience of in her business, she has been able to help her husband in taking care of the kids school expenses.

Adwoa obtains her supplies from the central market of Kumasi in the Ashanti region of Ghana and retails them to her customers through hawking. She wants to use the loan to buy more supplies of cooking oil and bags of rice etc., to increase her stock. She believes the loan would enable her to increase her savings to provide for the educational needs of her children.

Adwoa belongs to a village bank called ‘Good name’. She hopes to receive GHS 500 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her to save more to take care of the household.

loans.use: To buy more supplies of charcoal, cooking oil, and bags of rice, etc.

loans.name: Mondoukpè Bilikissou

texts.fr: Originaire de LAGBE un petit village du département de l'OUEME, dame Y. Bilikissou est née le 18/05/1979 à cotonou la capitale économique du BENIN. Elle est mariée à AKANDE Basitou un commerçant de profession. Elle a trois enfants dont deux garçons et une fille tous scolarisés. Elle exerce l'activité de la vente de divers; par exemple: les produits de beauté, de cheveux, sucre, lait liquide et en poudre, savons, détergents, biscuits, bombons et huile d'arachide. Elle va s'approvisionner à Tokpa (marché international du BENIN). Elle est à son troisième crédit pour soutenir son activité.
texts.en:
From LAGBE, a small village in OUEME County, Ms. Bilikissou Y. was born on May 18, 1979 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Mr. Basitou AKANDE, a merchant by trade, and has three children, including two boys and a girl, all of whom are in school. Her work involves selling various goods, for example: beauty products, hair products, sugar, whole milk and powdered milk, soap, detergents, cookies, candy, and peanut oil. She is going to get supplies in Tokpa (international marketplace of Benin). She is on her third loan for supporting her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beauty products, hair products, and various other goods

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy A. started her trade 2 years ago in Apatrapa community, a suburb of Kumasi where she lives. Mercy prepares and serves her customers with very tasty and good quality fish, and fresh vegetables like pepper, onions, tomatoes etc. Because of that many customers buy from her stand in the market. She is now 36 years old and married with four children. They are currently in school. She wants to use the loan to buy an increased stock of assorted fishes and vegetables to increase her sales and income to support her children’s education and business growth. 

Mercy belongs to a village bank called ‘Adwenpa’ which means Good mind. She hopes to receive GH¢500 to make progress in her business by restocking her inventory. This would enable her to save more in taking care of the household.

loans.use: To buy more stock of smoked fishes, peppers, tomatoes, onions etc.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.fr: Née le 17 Septembre 1982 à Porto-Novo. K. SONIA est originaire de KETOU une ville du département de l’OUEME-PLATEAU. Elle est mariée à GLANON Damien carroleur de profession et mère de quatre garçons dont l’aîné du nom de Gustave est au CM2 à l’école primaire publique de YENAWA DAHO. Le couple vit depuis 17 ans au quartier YENAWA, un quartier périphérique de la ville de Cotonou. K. SONIA mène depuis 6 ans l’activité de la vente ambulante des habits pour enfants. Elle va s’approvisionner à Tokpa le grand marché international du BENIN. Elle est à son quatrième crédit pour renforcer son activité.
texts.en:
Born on September 17, 1982 in Porto-Novo, Sonia K. is from KETOU, a city in OUEME-PLATEAU County. She is married to Damien GLANON, a tile mason by trade, and is the mother of four boys, the eldest of whom is named Gustave, in the 5th grade of the public school YENAWA DAHO. The couple have lived for seventeen years in YENAWA, an outlying district of the city of Cotonou. For six years, Ms.K.'s work has involved selling childrens' clothing door-to-door. She is going to stock up on supplies in Tokpa, the grand international marketplace of Benin. She is on her fourth loan for bolstering her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing for children

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys A. is 33 years old and a divorced woman with two children. Currently both her kids are in school. Gladys has been selling frozen foods like chicken, pork, mutton, fish, etc. in the local market of Apatrapa in the Kumasi for a year now. Through hard work and determination, Gladys is doing well in providing for the basic needs of her kids especially their education. Sometimes getting money to pay her kids' education fees becomes a challenge for her. As a single parent, she is doing all her possible best to cater for her kids through the income from the business she runs.

Gladys does not have adequate funds to support her business. This has affected her operation, especially in the face of increasing food prices in the marketplace. With the loan, she wants to purchase more cartons of frozen foods like fish, chicken, pork, and sausages to enable her to raise enough income to expand her sales. She would be grateful for your support.

Gladys belongs to a village bank called ‘Nyame naye’ which means "Good living". She hopes to receive GHS 500 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy cartons of frozen foods like fish, chicken, mutton, and smoked fish, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a new moto

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married with two sons - 11 and 12 years old. She sells children's clothing at the city market. Her gross monthly income is 9,000 UAH.

Irina has been in this business for 5 years. She used to sell clothes working for other small-business owners. Then she decided to start her own business. She is a very joyful and enthusiastic person. She works hard in spite of any difficulties she might have. Three month ago Irina got seriously injured in a car accident. She had to pay for her medical treatment by herself and took some money out of business. Now, the loan that she is asking for, 5,000 UAH, would help her to increase her assortment of goods and sustain her business.

loans.use: to increase the assortment of goods

loans.name: Zubaida Ali Akbar Group

texts.en:
Zubaida baji is a 35-year-old married lady and has resided in a city called Arifwala, Pakistan for the past 10 years. Zubaida baji is an uneducated lady and she doesn’t hesitate to mention the reason that her family didn't send her to school: they didn't know the worth of education. Her husband is also not an educated person. He has been a cloth merchant for the past 10 years. Zubaida baji is the mother of six kids: four boys and two girls. She sends all the children to school because she has a dream to give them a better living standard, and for this she sews clothes, taking orders from her neighbors. She uses her income to pay the school fees of her children. She is applying for a loan to buy cloth to expand her husband’s business.

She is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Azizan baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk-selling business. Shabana baji wants a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business. Nargis baji wants a loan to buy paint for her paint shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy cloth for her husband's cloth-selling business

loans.name: Antoinette

texts.fr: K. ANTOINETTE est née le 11 Juin 1980 à Cotonou, la capitale économique de la République du BENIN. Elle y est restée pour grandir, s'est mariée puis y mène actuellement ses activités génératrices de revenu. Elle est mère de 4 enfants ; un garçon et trois filles dont seuls les deux premiers sont scolarisés, les autres n’en ont pas encore l’âge. Elle s’est mariée à SOHOU Raphaël un mécanicien auto qui exerce son activité dans le centre ville de Cotonou. Elle vend des habits pour enfants et une bouillie faite à base d’amidon appelée Akpan dans la langue locale et qui est très appréciée par les béninois. Elle vend de façon ambulante et est aidée par sa petite sœur qui vit avec elle au quartier YENAWA ; un quartier périphérique de la ville de Cotonou Elle va s’approvisionner à Tokpa le grand marché international du BENIN. Elle est à son quatrième crédit pour renforcer ses activités.
texts.en:
ANTOINETTE K. was born on June 11, 1980 in Cotonou, the economic capital of BENIN. She stayed there to grow up, get married, and then earn an income, which is what she currently does. She is the mother of four children: a boy and three girls, of whom only the first two are in school, the others not being of age yet. Her husband is Raphaël SOHOU, an auto mechanic, who works in downtown Cotonou. Her work involves selling clothing for children and a porridge that is made from a starch called "akpan" in the local language and that is highly valued by the Beninese. She makes her sales door-to-door with the help from her younger sister, who lives with her in YENAWA, an outlying district in the city of Cotonou. Ms. K. is going to get supplies in Tokpa, the grand international marketplace of BENIN. She is on her fourth loan for bolstering her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy childrens' clothing and goods that go into making amidon porrridge

loans.name: Parveen Nazir Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Parveen baji is the wife of N. A. who is a transporter by profession and loads various items on his donkey cart and delivers them from one place to another. He has 30 years of experience in this business. Parven baji has resided in a city named Arifwala, Pakistan for the past 10 years.

Parveen baji is the mother of five children: four sons and one daughter. All of her children are getting education from a school which located near their house. Parveen baji and her husband are very happy to send their children to school. They feel themselves to be good parents. Parveen baji is involved in a clothes-sewing business. She has been sewing clothes since her children started going to school. She uses her income to pay the school fees of her children. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy a new donkey cart for her husband.

She is the leader of two-person group. The other member, Shamim baji, wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for transport. This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a donkey cart

loans.name: Khalida M.suleman Group

texts.en:
Khalida baji is a 52-year-old married lady and a citizen of a city called Arifwala, Pakistan for the past 25 years. She is married to a man whose name is M. S., and he is a mason by profession. She is the mother of four sons. Her eldest son has a plastic bottle-making business. Another is a daily wage labor. The others are getting an education from a school which located near their house.

Khalida baji loves her family and her family calls her a very loving mother. She always gets up early, although she is no longer young, and prepares breakfast for her family. She also helps her son in making plastic bottles. She is applying for a loan to buy plastic beans for making more plastic bottles to expand her son’s business.

She is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Kalsoom baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruit for sale. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for her transport business. Shagufta baji wants a loan to buy items (wires, switchboards) for her electrical items sales business. Khalida baji wants a loan to buy vegetables for her vegetable-selling business

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy plastic pellets for making plastic bottles

loans.name: Khadija M. Aslam Group

texts.en:
Khadija baji is a 48 year old married lady who has resided in the city of Arifwala, Pakistan for the past 20 years. Her husband, Mr. A. is a trader by profession. He deals with wheat and corn, which he buys in one place and sells in another place. He has been doing this work for 25 years. Khadija baji is the mother of three children; two sons and one daughter. Both of her sons are in the vegetable selling business. Her daughter is 15 years old, lives at home and helps her mother with  the clothes sewing  business. Khadija baji has taught her daughter, how to sew clothes. Now the daughter is an expert and can sew clothes by herself. Khadija baji invests the income in a banking committee and is planning to marry off her daughter when she has saved enough. 

Khadija baji is a group leader with several other women in her locality. She is applying for a loan to buy wheat and corn for her husband’s business. Mumtaz baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Zainab baji wants a loan to pay off the installments on her buffalo. Tasleem baji wants a loan to buy material (beads, colored thread and cloth) to expand her decorative embroider business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy wheat and corn

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To open a video club

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya is married with three children. She sells flowers, pictures and toys at a little store close to the city market. She has been in this business for 7 years. She has low competition and no low seasons for the goods she sells. Natalia is honest, open and a hard working person. The clients like her and the business goes well.

Nataliya would like to get a loan of 9,000 UAH to increase the assortment of her inventories. She hopes to continue this business despite difficult times that most small business owners are experiencing at the moment.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of inventories

loans.name: Sharifan Liaqat Group

texts.en:
Sharifan baji is a 52-year-old widow and has been a citizen of a city named Arifwala, Pakistan, for the past 25 years. She is a very hard-working lady. She started doing embroidery and stitching dresses after the death of her husband, to help with bringing up the children. She has three kids: two sons and one daughter. Her elder son is a loader. Another works in a workshop. Her daughter stays at home and helps her in making embroidered dresses. She is applying for a loan to buy a new donkey cart for her son because his old cart has became rough.

She is the group leader of some more women of her locality. Khalida baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk selling business. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Jamila begum baji wants a loan to buy vegetables to resell. Latifan baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a donkey cart

loans.name: Cresencia

texts.en:
Cresencia R. is 30 years old with one child.  Married at a young age, the couple settled in Gango, Ozamiz City. Her husband drives "tri-sikad" (3-wheeled motor transportation) from Mondays to Fridays.  For additional income he drives a multi-cab for hire on weekends.  Cresencia helps her husband by fish vending in the little barangay of Gango.  A small table is all they have to start up their business.  Neighbors, and people in the nearby barangays are her customers.  She never gets tired of making her display in a barangay market. She purchase fish from Bagsakan in the city market, or somewhere in Oroquieta City or Pagadian City.
She made arrangements for wholesale purchase of fish on a cash basis.  Cresencia's business has no trade or business name but she promptly pay taxes in the barangay.  They ask helped from Paglaum for additional capital for her fish selling.  The loan will also help her husband to generate income for their household. The couple aspires to increase more profit in order to have their own motorcycle for easy transportation. They also hope to have more income so that they can build their own house and be able to send her child to college.

loans.use: addtional working capital for fish selling

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua N. is thirty-six year old trader. She is married with six children who are currently attending school through the help of government free compulsory education. It is her daily dream to provide quality education for her children to give them better future lives.

Akua is the one you see in the photograph together with her daughter; she is crippled from childhood. You might think that she is squatting but that is the way she is. She finds it difficult to walk. But in spite of her predicament, she is still in business and Akua does things in the normal way. It amazes people when she goes to buy stocks of goods in the big market of Kumasi. Akua started her business with $50 but through determination and hard work, she has managed to expand her business. To me, that is an achievement because looking at her situation, there are few people who would do as well as she does. For this reason, she has been given recognition in the community through her hard work.

She lives in a community called Apatrapa in Kumasi. Within the community, there are diverse business activities and most of them are petty traders. Akua owns and operates a grocery shop with items like rice, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, assorted biscuits, candies, evaporated milk, etc.

She wants to use the loan to buy cartons of evaporated milk, bags of rice, canned foods, drinks and cooking oil to increase her stock of goods. With increased stock of different varieties, she hopes to make more income to provide for the educational needs of her children. She hopes to pay the loan in due time because she believes the loan will boost her business growth. Akua belongs to a village bank called ‘Adwenpa’ which means 'Good Mind'. She hopes to receive GH¢200 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her to save more for taking care of the household.

loans.use: To buy cartons of evaporated milk, bags of rice, canned foods, drinks, and cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena is married with one adult daughter. She rents a space in a fabric store and sells bed sheets and underwear. She has been in this business for 10 years. Elena treats her clients with a kind attitude and offers good products at good prices. Low competition for these types of goods helps Elena to make good sales. Her daughter helps her mother in the business - she buys the inventory and brings them to the store if needed urgently.

Elena would like to receive 9,000 UAH to increase the inventory. She hopes to sell more goods and spend extra income on improving her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To increase the inventory

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en: Nilda R., 39 years old lives in Rizal Avenue, Ozamiz City. She is married to Danilo and blessed with 5 children: the eldest is a high school student, 3 are in elementary grades, and the youngest is not yet in school. The family's source of income is from carenderia (small restaurant) while her husband is also a photographer and videographer. Nilda's carenderia started in January of 2006 with a profit of 800.00 pesos. At that time, they could not afford to provide the menu they desired. The family values their carenderia and tries to maintain a quality service. They manage to survive even when there is strong competition. They increased the number of options on the menu to give the customers more choices and as a result, private and public employees, students, and other commuters started dropping in. Paglaum has been a constant financing partner. They applied for an additional loan for her existing carenderia and to venture into a new field: barbecue selling. Their business allows them to purchase more stocks of drinks and meat for her business. She dreamed that someday her business can be seen not only in Ozamiz city, but also in other places in Misamis Occidental.Their greatest desire is for all their children to finishschool and to have a job for a better future.

loans.use: additional capital for "carenderia" business

loans.name: Abd Allah

texts.en:
Abd Allah is a 33-year-old man who lives in Bourj el Barajneh in the southern suburbs of Lebanon with his wife and their two children. Abd Allah has been working with handicrafts for twelve years. He makes the frames for photographs and paintings.

Abd Allah has requested a loan of 1200 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase frames for his work. Abd Allah has been a microcredit client for seven years now and has always paid on time.

His previous loans have influenced his life in a good way; thanks to the loans, he has been able to improve his work and his family situation. Abd Allah is special in his work because he is talented and he does very nice work. When he first started his business, he had difficulty building networks. His clients are his friends, neighbors and others. He decided on doing this business because he studied graphic design.

loans.use: Abd Allah will use the loan to purchase frames for his work.

loans.name: Abir

texts.en:
Abir is a 24-year-old woman who lives in Bourj el Barajneh, southern suburbs of Lebanon, with her husband and their child. Abir has been working as a hairdresser for eight years. She requested a loan of 700 US Dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase beauty products for her work. This is the first time that Abir has requested a loan.

Abir is special in her work she does it well and she is fast. Her clients are her friends, neighbors and others. When she first started her business, she had to organize her time between her work and her business. Abir decided on doing her business because she always wanted to be a hairdresser and she is a motivated person, especially when it comes to her work. In the future, she plans on opening a salon.

loans.use: Abir will use the loan to purchase beauty products for her work.

loans.name: Hafez

texts.en:
Hafez is a 37-year-old man who lives in Bourj el Barajneh, southern Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. He has been a car repairer for six years. He sells and repairs spare parts. Hafez has requested a loan of 700 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase new spare parts for his work. This is his second cycle and he has always paid on time.

His previous loan helped him improve his work. Hafez is special in his work because his garage is well positioned. His clients are his friends, neighbors and others. When he first started, he didn’t have the startup capital. Hafez decided on doing his business because he had experience in it. In the future, he plans to expand his business and diversify his merchandise.

loans.use: Hafez will use the loan to purchase new spare parts for his work.

loans.name: Bassam

texts.en: Bassam is a 29-year-old man who lives in Bourj el Barajneh, southern suburbs of Lebanon, with his wife and their child. Bassam has been working as a taxi driver for a year. He requested a loan of 1000 US Dollars from Al Majmoua in order to do some maintenance work on his taxi. This is the first time that Bassam has requested a loan. His clients can be anybody. In the future, he plans to purchase a new car.

loans.use: Bassam will use the loan to do some maintenance work on his taxi.

loans.name: Ludivina

texts.en: In Gango, Ludivina D. is enjoying her vegetable selling. She is 38 years old, married, and has 4 kids. Her husband works as a laborer.  Ludivina thought of putting up vegetable vending.  Since Ludivina has to pay a large sum of interest from a lender she hasn’t been able to sell different types of vegetables.  With the  loan they hope to increase the sales volume and have more profit so they can have a mode of transportation to import/export vegetables. More than anything else they wish to provide quality education for her children.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of vegetables

loans.name: Constancia

texts.en: Mrs. Constancia E. is 44 years old, married, and lives in Roxas, Zamboanga del Norte. She has four children, and they are all in school in the local town. Her husband is a government employee, but his income is not sufficient to sustain the needs of their family. In order to help her husband, she sells basic commodities in front of their house. Originally she began selling vinegar, soy sauce, edible oil etc. Now she thinks she must expand her business, and fortunately she heard of Paglaum MPC, where she decided to join last Jan.30, 2008. She availed loans for 3 times already, but has not received a loan. Now, she is applying for $175 to buy gallons of edible oil, soy sauce, canned goods, and soft drinks.   In the future, her dreams will be fulfilled if she sees her children finish school and obtain comfortable careers. She also wanted to expand her sari-sari store into a mini grocery store.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for her sari-sari store ( softdriks,basic commodities)

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
Geraldine O. is 28 years old, married, and lives in Roxas, Zamboanga in Del Norte. Geraldine married at an early age, and became the responsible parent she is today. She began her own business vending snacks in December of 2007. In order to increase her revenue and capital, she decided to apply for loans from several institutions. As a result, Geraldine was able to create her own store where she can cook Tempura, a snack made from flour and fish, as well as Buco, a coconut fruit juice.

Geraldine believes that her culinary services are accessible to both adults and children, and in part contributes to the success she has been enjoying. She is currently applying for a loan to increase the amount of tempura and buco she can produce in her stand. Geraldine hopes to be able to use the revenue she earns to help her children finish school and achieve a more successful and comfortable life.

loans.use: to buy "Tempora" & Buco (coconut fruit)  for her rolling store

loans.name: Miguel

texts.en: Mr. Miguel A. J.., 33 years old, is married and lives in Katipunan, Zamboanga Del Norte. He has 2 children. He has a “carenderia” (a small restaurant) where that he and his wife run. His restaurant started small and but has rapidly grown. His customers include people in his neighborhood and passers-by such as truck drivers and pedestrians. Miguel is requesting 20,000PHP to renovate his carenderia and to buy meat and spices as well. He hopes to provide a comfortable life to his family by continuing to grow his restaurant to make more money.

loans.use: Renovation of Carenderia and buy meats & spices

loans.name: Alba Esperanza

texts.es:
Doña Alba Esperanza G. P. tiene la edad de 61 años, su estado civil es soltera, Doña Alba no tiene hijos solo tiene 1 nieto a su cargo de la edad de 17 años y cursa el 4 año de secundaria, Doña Alba no tiene compañero de vida, los propósitos de Doña Alba son de mantener su negocio activo para que este le siga generando ingresos a pesar del incremento de la gasolina ya que tiene que recorrer las calles en busca de pasajeros los sueños de Doña Alba son de adquirir otra unidad de transporte para que su nieto lo administre y pueda obtener experiencia en este tipo de negocio y este sea otro medio de trabajo y así pueda mantenerse para el día de mañana sus deseos son  que  el nivel de vida del país mejore ya que la ayuda de muchos países donantes son importante ya que son los refuerzos de las personas que realmente lo necesitan.

La actividad económica son los servicios de taxi, la ubicación de su negocio es de forma ambulante, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 4 años, Doña Alba inicia este negocio como una alternativa de generar ingresos y este servicio de taxi lo obtuvo al vender un negocio de granos básicos que poseía en el mercado del mayoreo en Managua conocido como el Bisne y por medio de los financiamientos que también fueron  necesarios para este negocio al principio Doña Alba no poseía muchos conocimientos de este tipo de negocio y así la persona quien se encargaba de prestarle los servicios como chofer le entregaba poco dinero y de esta forma no le proporcionaba ganancias y con el apoyo de su familia logran designar a una persona confiable para este cargo y es así que por medio del tiempo transcurrido alcanza la experiencia en este negocio pero todavía necesita un financiamiento propuesto para capital de trabajo para proporcionarle mejoras a la unidad de trabajo como seria el cambio de radiador, llantas entre otras cosas y reconoce la ayuda de la Fundación León 2000 y las organizaciones amigas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Alba Esperanza G. P. is a single, 61 years old woman. She has no children, just one nephew in her care that is 17 years old and in his 4th year of secondary school. Alba doesn't have a partner in life. Her purpose is to keep her business active so that it continues to earn her income in spite of the increase in the cost of gas, now that she has to go through the streets looking for passengers. Alba hopes to acquire another vehicle so that her nephew can manage it and get experience in this type of business. That way, he'll have another means of work so he can help himself in the days to come. She hopes that the quality of life in her country will improve, given that the help of other donor countries is so important, since it supports the people that really need it. Her main economic activity is providing taxi services, and it is located throughout the city. She has four years of experience at her work. Alba started this business as an alternative way of earning money. She got the taxi service by selling a business selling whole grains that she had in the wholesale market of Bisne in Managua and through other necessary financing arrangements. Alba didn't have a lot of knowledge about this type of business at first, so the person she hired as the driver turned in very little money and didn't distribute the earnings. With the help of her family, she managed to find a reliable person for this job. Over time, she has gained experience in the business, but she still needs the requested financing to fund the business so that she can make improvements to her vehicle, including changing the radiator, tires, and other things. She acknowledges the support of Fundación León 2000 and its sister organizations.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repairs to her vehicle

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Alaa

texts.en: Alaa is a 34-year-old man who is married and has four young children. He and his family live in Sabra, Beirut. He inherited a car body shop from his father, after working in the shop for 20 years. Today, he wants to borrow $1200 so he can add a car accessories section to further expand his business.

loans.use: Buy car accessories

loans.name: Maria De Los Angeles

texts.es:
La Señora de María de los Ángeles A. García tiene la edad de 50 años, su estado civil es soltera, Doña María no tiene hijos solo tiene un nieto a su cargo y tiene la edad de 25 años y cursa el 4 año de secundaria, sus propósitos son incrementar su inventario para obtener mas productos que ofrecer a sus clientes sus deseos son de mejorar el nivel de vida para su familia ya que la situación del país esta muy difícil y es así como le demuestra a su nieto que tiene que esforzarse por tener un medio de ingresos que le ayude en un futuro para sus propios hijos los sueños de Doña Maria son de preparar profesionalmente a su nieto ya que es importante para su vida misma y para el de la sociedad ya que es importante en esta situación en la que el país se encuentra obtener un grado de aprendizaje mucho mas alto y lograr cumplir metas para su vida misma.

Su actividad económica es una pulpería en la que ofrece los productos como: golosinas, café, cigarrillos, pan, refrescos naturales entre otras cosas, la ubicación de su negocio es en su casa de habitación, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 6 años, Doña María inicia este negocio por la necesidad de tener una actividad económica para  el sustento de su familia por lo que al principio inicio con capital propio ya que trabajo en el extranjero y con esto que pudo recaudar decidió venirse a su país de origen y establecer una pulpería con pocos productos como: caramelos, gaseosas, huevo y  jabón y con esto no lograba satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes  por lo que decide realizar un préstamo con Fundación León 2000 iniciando así un nuevo portal de ayuda para ella es por eso que ahora necesita del financiamiento para la inversión de su capital de trabajo en lo que consiste la compra de: gaseosa, granos básicos tarjetas telefónicas y productos de limpieza por lo que retribuye  a Fundación León 2000 y las organizaciones amigas que muestran el interés por sacar adelante a la gente que le gusta trabajar.
texts.en:
Mrs. María de los Ángeles A. García is 50 years old and single. She has no children, just one nephew in her care who is 25 years old and in his 4th year of secondary. Her intent is to increase her inventory so that she has more products to offer her customers. She wants to improve the quality of life for her family since the situation in her country is very difficult. This is how she will show her nephew that you have to work hard to earn a living, which will help him in the future with his own children. Maria dreams that her nephew will be prepared professionally since it's important for his own life and to society, since in the difficult situation the country finds itself in, it's important to achieve a high level of learning and accomplish your own life goals. Her main economic activity is running a grocery store where she sells products like cookies, coffee, cigarettes, bread, juice drinks, and more. She runs her business out of her home, and has owned the business for six years. María began her business out of need to have some economic means of supporting her family. She began with her own money from working abroad. With the money that she could save up, she decided to return to her native country and open a grocery store with a few products such as caramels, soda, eggs, and ham. This couldn't satisfy the demand of her customers, so she decided to take out a loan with Fundación León 2000, thus opening a new means of support for herself. She currently needs financing to invest in her work by buying sodas, basic cereals, telephone cards, and cleaning products. She will repay Fundación León and its sister organizations that take interest in helping people who want to work get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: capital de trabajo

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en: Mohammad Ali is a 38-year-old man who is married and has three children. He and his family live in Saida, Southern Lebanon. He has worked as a fisherman for 20 years, and bought his first fishing boat in 1999. Today, Mohammad Ali wants to perform maintenance on his boat for increased safety, therefore he is requesting a loan of $1100.

loans.use: Repair the fishing boat

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Candida Rosa

texts.es:
La Señora de Nombre Candida Rosa M. tiene la edad de 35 años, su estado civil es casada, Doña Candida tiene 2 hijos sus edades son las siguientes su hijo mayor de 15 años de edad cursa el 4 año de secundaria y su hijo menor de 9 años cursa el 3 grado de primaria, su compañero de vida labora con su esposa, sus propósitos son de mantener su negocio activo ya que este es la fuente de ingresos mas importante para su familia y es por medio de su negocio que puede ofrecerle a sus hijos el pan de cada día en sus deseos esta el  de proporcionarle mejoras a su vivienda por lo que son necesarias para que su familia pueda vivir  mejor ya que debido a lo poco que gana no ha podido realizar los cambios que desea para con su vivienda sus sueños son que sus hijos se formen de manera profesional ya que Doña Candida ha hecho muchos sacrificios para que sus hijos puedan tener estudio, vestimenta y hogar también en sus sueños esta que todas las personas aprendan a reciclar para tener limpio nuestro planeta.

La actividad económica de Doña Candida es la recolecta de chatarra como: hierro, papel, cobre y aluminio la ubicación de su negocio es en su casa de habitación, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 14 años, cuando Doña Candida inicia este negocio fue con un monto pequeño y con capital propio ya que ella misma consiguo el dinero para establecer el negocio, es  un trabajo muy difícil ya que se debe caminar mucho hasta juntar la cantidad suficiente por libras, luego llevarla hasta su casa de habitación y hasta entonces se trasladan las chatarras ya pesadas a las empresas recicladoras ubicadas en los diferentes países de Centroamérica, esto es un proceso largo, su esposo la apoyo en este negocio quien mas tarde empezó a trabajar con ella y actualmente ambos generan ingresos para su familia, Doña Candida utilizara el financiamiento para capital de trabajo por que ella debe pagar gastos de transporte, la compra del papel para reciclar, el hierro y el aluminio, ya que en las recolectas que realiza no obtiene mucho material y se le hace necesario comprar los materiales a otras personas que llegan a ofertarlas a la casa de Doña Candida.
texts.en:
Candida Rosa M. is 35 years old, married, and has 2 children. Her eldest son is 15 years old and is in his 4th year of secondary school, and her youngest son who is 9 years old is in the 3rd grade in primary school. Her life partner works with his wife, and their purpose is to maintain the business active, as it is the most important source of income for the family, and is the means by which they have been able to provide for their sons. Amongst their wishes is to be able to carry out much needed home improvements so that the family can live better. Due to the fact that she earns very little, Candida has not been able to realize the changes that she wishes for their home. Her dream is that her sons graduate and become professionals given that Candida has made many sacrifices so that her sons could carry out their studies, have clothing on their back, and a home. She also dreams that all people will learn to recycle so that we can preserve a clean planet. Candida’s main economic activity is the collection of junk goods such as: iron, paper, copper, and aluminum. Candida has owned her business for 14 years and it is located in the home in which she lives. When Candida began her business it was with a small amount and with her own capital since she herself found the money to establish her business. It is a very difficult job due to the fact that she has to walk a lot until she has collected a sufficient quantity by pounds, she then takes it to her home, where the heavy collections of junk goods are later moved to recycling companies located in the different countries of Central America. This is a long process, her husband who supported her in this business venture later began working with her, and currently they both generate income for their family. Candida will use this loan as capital for her work since she has to pay for transportation costs, and the purchase of the paper to recycle, iron, and aluminum given that during the collection rounds that she carries out she does acquire a lot of material, and as such it is necessary for her to buy materials from other people who arrive to offer them at Candida’s home.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business capital to cover transportation costs and the purchase of materials.

loans.name: Souad

texts.en: Souad is a 43-year-old woman who is married, with three children. She and her family live in Saida, Southern Lebanon. She started working from her house in 1995 to help her husband with the household expenses. Souad sells home appliances and kitchenware to her neighbors and friends. Today, she wants to borrow $1200 to buy more inventory to increase her client base.

loans.use: Buy more inventory

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en:
Yaa A. is 36 years old. She is a divorced woman with 1 brilliant child. Yaa is so proud of her son because he is academically good. Her son's performance manifests during his exams and his teachers confirm it. Her son is in the senior high school. Yaa lives with her family at Apatrapa in the Ashanti region of Ghana. For the past fifteen years all that Yaa has been doing to take care of her household is baking bread.

Yaa bakes bread and supplies it to the town around her and also sells some to individuals. Demand for the bread has increased as a result of constant supply and just-in-time (JIT) delivery. Her customers book their order in advance and before they come it is be ready. She says the price of commodities is increasing which is making it difficult to buy more raw materials from the market. And the daily demand for bread is high. She says she bakes at most 1000 loaves of bread in a day.

Yaa needs the loan to buy more bags of flour, sugar, margarine, milk, and firewood, etc. to restock her inventory. Her dream is to secure a better future for her lovely son through her selfless hard work. That is quality education. Yaa belongs to a village bank called ‘Adwenpa’ which means "Good mind". She hopes to receive GHS 450 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her to save more for taking care of their household.

loans.use: To buy baking materials like bags of flour, sugar, margarine, yeast, and firewood, etc.

loans.name: Wilfredo Danilo

texts.es:
Este Señor de Nombre Wilfredo Danilo E. N. tiene la edad de 25 años, su estado civil es casado, Don Wilfredo tiene 1 hijo de la edad de 6 años que recientemente cursa el 6 grado de primaria, su compañera de vida labora como costurera, sus propósitos son de incrementar su negocio para lograr mejores ingresos ya que así no tendría problemas económicos como los tiene hoy, sus deseos son de son establecer su negocio por lo que el es un vendedor ambulante y también establecer un negocio para su esposa ya que ambos puedan trabajar de forma humilde y así le proporcione ingresos para su familia sus sueños son obtener una mejor calidad de vida logrando darle mejoras su propiedad ya que con esfuerzo la compro y ahora quiere acondicionarla  para que sus hijo pueda tener un lugar digno y adecuado donde vivir ya que también en sus deseos esta el darle a su hijo todo lo necesario para que el día de mañana no pase necesidades.

La actividad económica a la que se dedica es venta de mercadería en general y ofrece lo siguiente: sillas, bolsos, zapatos, ropa, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 3 años, la ubicación de su negocio es de forma ambulante, Don Wilfredo inicio este negocio por un amigo quien fue el encargado de de que Wilfredo entrara en el negocio por lo que al Principio solo contaba con la poca experiencia obtenida de su Mama por lo que poco a poco le fu tomando cariño a su trabajo y comenzó ofreciendo pequeñas cosas como: sabanas, toallas y cuadros por lo que al ofrecer el producto al cliente mostraba timidez y le costaba por lo que dice que no fue tan fácil ingresar en este tipo de negocio pero no se dio por vencido y lucho para quedarse con esta fuente de ingresos para mantener a su familia por lo que necesita el financiamiento Don Wilfredo tiene que conseguir la mercadería a un precio favorable ya que el realiza la distribución de los productos que le hacen por encargos y así pueda ganarse la eficacia que tiene con sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mr. Wilfredo Danilo E. N. is 25 years old, married and has a 6-year-old son who recently began elementary school. His wife works as a seamstress. His intentions are to increase his business in order to earn a better income so that he will not have the same economic problems that he has today. His wishes are to establish his business as a street vendor and also to establish a business for his wife so that both can work and earn a modest living.

Mr. Wilfredo’s family dreams of a better quality of life; he wants to improve his property, which with much effort he bought. Mr. Wilfredo wants to remodel his property so that his son can have a decent and adequate place to live. He also desires to give his son all that he will need for the future.

Mr. Wilfredo sells merchandise such as: chairs, handbags, shoes and clothing. He has run his traveling business for 3 years. He began his business through a friend who acted as the manager. In the beginning Mr. Wilfredo relied on the little experience he had obtained from his mother to start his business. He lovingly grew his business little by little and began offering small things such as: sheets, towels and decorative pictures. While attempting to sell his products to his customers he was a little timid at first which cost him business and it was not easy to commit to this type of job. He fought to remain a business owner in order to maintain the livelihood of his family. Mr. Wilfredo will use the loan to obtain merchandise at a favorable price and sell it to his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Breanne Kochert, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is 20-year-old young man, who lives in Adloun, Southern Lebanon. Ahmad worked in his father's shop for eight years, and then he opened his own aluminum shop a couple of years ago. Because he is dedicated to his work, his clientele has grown rapidly in the past year. Today, Ahmad wants to borrow $1200 in order to buy a new machine to cut aluminum sheets with better accuracy.

loans.use: Buy a new machine

loans.name: Moisei

texts.en:
Moisei G. lives in Floritoaea Veche village, Ungheni district. Ms. G. is a person with serious intent, punctual and responsible, calculated. She is married and has a good reputation. She works as a deputy on the instructive process in a gymnasium. She has been working since September 1990. 

According to salary certificates, Ms. G. receives an average monthly salary  of 2460 lei. Ms. G. has received a loan in the amount of 5000 to purchase pigs. Our client's plan is to raise pigs in order to sell pork at the central market.In her business she is helped by her husband. The purpose of the loan is to increase the number of pigs.

loans.use: to increase the number of pigs she raises

loans.name: Ragheb

texts.en: Ragheb is a 24-year-old young man who owns a small car body paint shop in Babilia, Southern Lebanon. He has been serving his small community since 2004, and has found an opportunity to expand his business into other areas. In order to fulfill his project and to fix more cars in his garage, Ragheb needs to buy new tools. That is why he is requesting a loan of $1000.

loans.use: Buy new tools

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To supply his store

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Fatou est jeune fille agée de 23 ans quivit à Mbour avec ses parents qui  n'ont pas baucoups de moyens .Pour aider ses parents et survenir à ses besoins personnels elle produit  depuis trois ans (03)des jus fruit qu'elle vend à la gare  routiére.Avec le prêt sollicité ,elle veut renforcer  ses capacités de production  pour accroitre ses revenus.
texts.en:
Fatou is a 23-year old woman who lives in Mbour with her parents who do not have a lot of financial resources. To help her parents and provide for her own needs, she's been making and selling fruit juices at the bus station for three years. With the loan she's seeking, she wants to bolster her business to increase her income.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster her fruit juices business

loans.name: Benkadi (Bonne Entente) Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkadi de l’association Saramaya II  (composé de 4 femmes  mariées) ont une moyenne d’âge de 27 ans et 2 enfants. Elles résident dans des familles polygames dans le quartier  Hamdallaye de la ville de Sikasso(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles  exercent des activités commerciales différentes mais la plus dominante est la vente d’habits pour enfants, des chaussures en plastique et la vente du bois de chauffe.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y’a 1an. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).Le prêt précédent a été correctement remboursé.
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 2 douzaines d’habits pour enfants quelques paires de chaussures en plastique et 1 vingtaine de chargements de charrettes en  bois de chauffe.
 Elles s’approvisionnent soit sur place à Sikasso ville (3eme Région administrative du Mali) ou dans les villages environnants. Les produits sont vendus en détail et la plupart au comptant dans les marchés de la ville de Sikasso (tel le marché de Médine et le grand marché de la ville) et dans le quartier, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 17 000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités. Elles envisagent devenir des grossistes.
texts.en:
The members of the group Benkadi of the association Saramaya II is made up of four women who are on average 27 years old and have on average two children. They live in polygamous families in the neighborhood of Hamdallaye in the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali).

They practice different trades but the main one is the sale of children clothing, plastic shoes, and the sale of firewood for heating. They have collaborated with the institution Soro Yiriwaso for one year. This is their second solidarity loan (group loan). The previous loan was fully reimbursed.

They are planning on using this loan to buy two dozens children outfits, a few pairs of plastic shoes, and twenty cart loads of firewood for heating.

They stock up either on the spot in Sikasso town (third administrative region of Mali) or in the neighboring villages. The goods are sold retail and most of the time for cash at the markets in the town of Sikasso (such as the market of Médine and the large town market), and in the neighborhood. They sell to customers made up of women and men. They hope to each make a profit of 17 000 FCFA per month. They will use it to provide for their families’ needs and invest the rest in their businesses. They would like to become wholesalers.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of children clothing, plastic shoes and firewood

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en: Amelia is powerful figure in her Bank of Hope. She operates a successful used-clothing business that gives her community access to clothing. She and her son live in a "batey" (sugarcane community) outsiD. of San Pedro D. Macoris. She would use this loan for a cement floor. Cement floors promote hygiene and health, and they are durable.  Please help the Esperanza Home Improvement Department make her dream come true. Thank you!

loans.use: A new cement floor

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To supply her shop

loans.name: Benkadi (Bonne Entente) Group

texts.fr:
Les sept femmes du groupe Benkadi de l’association Sérieux  de Bougoula Ville(toutes  mariées), ont en moyenne  28 ans et 2 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies  dans le quartier  Bougoula ville de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mlai).
Elles  exercent la même activité commerciale à savoir la vente de pomme de terre et  quelques fois des patates, des choux pommés et  de la banane plantain. Pour mener à bien leur activité et  satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle, ils sont à leur huitième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).Les prêts précédents se sont bien dénoués.
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 5 sacs de 100kg de pomme de terre. Elles s’approvisionnent sur place à Sikasso ville (3eme Région administrative du Mali) et dans les villages environnants auprès des paysans producteurs.
Les produits sont vendus en détail et au comptant dans les différents marchés de la ville de Sikasso (Médine, grand marché de la ville), dans le quartier à domicile à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes et de quelques hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 27 000 FCFA par mois qu’elles utiliseront pour soutenir les conjoints dans la prise en charge de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités. 
Chacune d’elle souhaite devenir une grossiste en allant au prêt individuel..
texts.en:
The seven women (all married) of the group Benkadi of the association Sérieux de Bougoula Ville average 28 years of age and two children. They live in traditional extended families in the Bougoula Ville district of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They each do the same kind of commerce, namely the sale of potatoes and sometimes sweet potatoes, cabbages, and plantains. To carry out their work and satisfy their customers, they are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they are on their eighth solidarity loan (group loan). The preceding loans were settled.

The group members plan to use this loan to buy five 100-kg sacks of potatoes. They stock up locally in Sikasso and in surrounding villages from peasant growers. The goods are sold retail for cash in the different marketplaces of Sikasso (Médine, the grand marketplace of the city) and in the district out of their homes. Customers are composed essentially of women and some men.

The group members each hope to realize a monthly profit of 27,000 francs CFA that they will use to support their spouses in caring for their families and to invest the rest in their businesses. Each of the women in the group would like to become a wholesaler while taking out individual loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy potatoes

loans.name: Etoile Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Etoile (composé de 5 femmes  mariées) ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans avec en moyenne 2 enfants. Elles résident dans le quartier  Hamdallaye dans des foyers polygames dans la ville de Sikasso.(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali)
Elles  exercent des activités commerciales différentes mais la plus dominante est la vente de bananes en plus, elles font la vente du bois de chauffe, des boissons non alcoolisées et  la restauration.
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle les membres de ce groupe ont intégré l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle, ils sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).Le prêt précédent a été correctement dénoué.
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 24 régimes de bananes, 18 casiers de boissons non alcoolisées, 2 chargements de camionnette en bois de chauffe, 3 paquets d’ingrédients divers (condiments alimentaires) et un sac de riz. Elles s’approvisionnent soit à Bamako (capitale du Mali),  ou sur place à Sikasso ville  et dans les villages environnants. Les produits sont vendus en détail et au comptant dans les marchés de la ville de Sikasso et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 20. 500 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités. Elles ambitionnent très prochainement l’aménagement du restaurant, aller faire le chargement de camionnettes en régimes de bananes jusque dans les plantations, ouverture d’un dépôt de boissons etc.
texts.en:
The members of the group Etoile (composed of five married women) average 32 years of age and two children. They reside in the Hamdallaye district in polygamous homes in the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They do different commercial work but predominant is the sale of bananas. In addition, they sell firewood and soft drinks and do catering.

In order to satisfy their customers, the group members have joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they are on their second solidarity loan (group loan). The preceding loans have been correctly settled. They plan to use this loan to buy 24 bunches of bananas, 18 cases of soft drinks, 2 truck-loads of firewood, 2 packets of various ingredients (condiments), and 1 sack of rice. They stock up either in Bamako (capital of Mali) or locally in Sikasso and surrounding villages. The goods are sold retail for cash in the different marketplaces of Sikasso and in the district to customers composed of women and men.

The group members each hope to realize a monthly profit of 20,500 francs CFA that will be used to provide for their families and to invest the rest in their businesses. Their ambition is to fix up a restaurant very shortly, to load up trucks with bananas from plantations, and to open an outlet for beverages, etc.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bananas, firewood, beverages, and ingredients for catering

loans.name: Candida Rosa

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Masaya la señora Candida Rosa H. se ha destacado por laborar en su negocio de venta de carne teniendo su propio establecimiento en su casa de habitación donde se desempeña con mucho esfuerzo y gran dedicación.

Ella es madre de tres hijos de los cuales dos de ellos se encuentran en edad escolar y necesitan de todo el apoyo de su madre para salir adelante y lograr coronar una carrera universitaria. 
Como todo negocio en desarrollo, la señora Candida hoy en día necesita la compra de la carne para comercializarla en su establecimiento y es por esta razón que ella ha acudido a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con un crédito para que de esta forma al brindársele dicho crédito pueda comprar la carne y comercializarla.
texts.en:
In the city of Masaya, Candida Rosa H. has stood out for working at her business selling meats. She has her own establishment, located in her home, where she carries out her activities with a great deal of effort and dedication. She is the mother of three children, two of whom are still in school and need all her help and support to get ahead and pursue university degrees and careers. As with all businesses in development, Candida currently needs to purchase meats to sell at her establishment. For this reason, she has turned to Ceprodel to benefit from credit in order to bring her products to market.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase meats.

loans.name: Lumière Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Lumière (composé de 4 femmes  mariées) ont une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans avec en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles résident dans le quartier  Hamdalaye de la ville de Sikasso(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles exercent des activités commerciales différentes mais la plus dominante est la vente d’habits pour enfants à laquelle s’ajoute la vente d’essence et de boissons (sucrerie)
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso pour satisfaire les besoins de leur clientèle il y a 1 an. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).Le prêt précédent a été correctement remboursé.
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 2 douzaines de vêtements  pour enfants, une vingtaine de casier de sucrerie et 1 baril de 100litres d’essence. 
Elles s’approvisionnent sur place à Sikasso ville auprès des grossistes. Les produits sont vendus en détail et  au comptant dans les marchés de la ville de Sikasso et dans quartier à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 11000 FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the group Lumière are composed of four married women who average 34 years of age and three children. They reside in the Hamdalaye district of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They do different commercial work, but predominant is the sale of children's clothing, plus gasoline and soft drinks.
