She learned this business from her mother. She needs the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more kerosene to sell. She is 49 years old and married with five children. She says thanks to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en: Thelma D., married with 5 children, lives in Poblacion, Panaon, Misamis Occidental. She and her husband run a bakery and store. She has three married children who all attended school and are employed. She has two more children, both in high school, who help her at her bakery. The couple is trying to sustain and expand their bakery and store. In 1989 when she started her business it was small, but it has grown since in large part due to its location in the corner of the market. Their business profits are used to pay for the education of their two youngest children. Thelma is requesting 15,000 PHP to invest more in their store, especially for sari-sari store. She hopes that eventually her bakery will be large enough to be a local distributor of baked goods.

loans.use: additional capital for her sari-sari store in support to her bakeshop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To supply her shop

loans.name: Joyce's Group

texts.en: M. Joyce, 50, is the chairperson of Kyosiga Women’s group in Kayunga, Uganda. She is married with 3 grown up children and cares for 8 grandchildren at home. She has a farming business, supplying fresh beans, potatoes, and cassava to schools.  Payments for her produce are usually made each week. She also sells ladies clothes, mostly underwear, to offices, hospitals, schools, and private homes as a side business. Over the years, she has been able to build a trusted customer base and in most cases she now just supplies her customers directly.   Joyce needs her portion of this group loan to buy more clothes for sale and seeds for cultivation.

loans.use: To buy clothes for sale and seeds for planting.

loans.name: Olena

texts.en:
Olena is married and has two grown children. She rents a space in a hardware store and sells various tools and materials used in construction and remodeling.

Olena has been in this business for 5 years. This business is one of the most relevant and profitable in the area. The store has a good downtown location. Her good assortment brings in many clients.

Olena would like a loan of 9,000 UAH to increase her inventory. At the moment, she can buy tools at a low price to sell later and make additional profit. Olena's business goal is to have her own store instead of renting from someone else.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Shakirat

texts.en: Shakirat is 31 years old and married with a child. She is a client of LAPO (Kiva's Field Partner). She sells frozen foods like chicken, turkey, fish etc. She has been in this business for a long time. Shakirat needs the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more frozen foods to sell. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Abike

texts.en: Abike sells prayers items like incense, olive oils, crucifixes etc. She has been in this business for a long time. Abike is 46 years old and married with two children. She needs the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more prayer times to sell. She hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She says thanks to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more prayer items to sell

loans.name: Rania

texts.en:
Rania is a 31-year-old woman who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with her husband and their four children. Rania has owned a grocery store for seven years. She also sells vegetables, chicken, cigarettes and canned foods. 

Rania has requested a loan of $1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her shop. This is the first time that Rania has requested a loan.

Rania’s clients are her friends and neighbors. When she first started her business, her business was a bit slow, but now that she is well known, that is not the case anymore. Rania decided to enter this business because of her family's financial situation. She also wanted to help her husband by supplementing her family’s income. In the future, she plans to expand her business by opening a supermarket.

loans.use: Rania will use the loan to purchase merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
In the little town of San Vicente Bajo, Oroquieta City, Marilou O., 45 years old, is operating a "sari-sari" (variety) business. Her husband is a local government employee and they are blessed with 2 adorable kids . They paid for the education of their 2 children with the profits from their business. Marilou has been interested in business and she wants to continue her passion while supporting her husband. Their primary customers are their neighbors. The family would like to venture into rice trading. They want to help their neighborhood by providing a store that sells all basic goods. The foundation of this business is not possible without the help of kiva. Paglaum MPC came as a financing partner for their capital needs. They applied for a PHP $325 loan to purchase additional stocks for their store and for a start up of rice trading as well.
Marilou and her husband have a big wish for their kids to finish their studies and above all for their business to flourish with a permanent store to display with of their inventories.

loans.use: additional capital for her sari-sari store and rice trading

location.town: San Vicente Bajo, Oroquieta City Misamis Occidenta

loans.name: Andrei

texts.en:
For more than10 years, Andrei’s main activity has been growing potatoes and vegetables. He started to work with his parents. Now he has extended his business by adding his wife. He processes 0.77 hectares of arable land and has a 150-square-meter greenhouse in the yard. Now he has decided to dig a well to irrigate the potatoes and vegetables. The business is located in Dubasari. 

This loan is Andrei's third loan from MicroInvest. The first loan, to raise potatoes, was granted in December 2007. The second loan, in the amount of 20,000 lei ($2,000 USD), was granted in February 2008, and was used to raise potatoes, tomatoes, cabbage and melons. The purpose of this loan is to dig a well to have an easy access to water for irrigation. His future plan is to increase agricultural production and to start growing other types of vegetables.

loans.use: To dig an irrigation well

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is 43 years old and married with two children. She is a client of LAPO (Kiva's Field Partner). She sells frozen foods like chicken, turkey, and fish. Margaret needs the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more frozen foods to sell. She is indeed grateful to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Paz Y Amor Group

texts.en:
Alcy E. is the coordinator of group 5, in the Bank of Hope Paz y Amor, which has 30 borrowers divided among 6 groups of 5 people. The five people in her group are involved in various businesses and will share the loan.
 
Alcy E. is 40 years old. She is married; her husband is 38. They have two girls, 17 and 19 years old. E. works as a street vendor, selling clothes, shoes, and also food. She works in the district of Sosua. She previously received a loan from Esperanza. This will be her second loan. The first loan made it possible for her to expand her business and increase her monthly sales. With her new loan she hopes to increase her sales even further. Alcy E. hopes that one day will be able to buy a nice house for her family. She is also concerned about the future of her children. Her oldest child has completed a year of medical school, and Alcy E. hopes to see her daughter become a doctor.

loans.use: To buy shoes and clothes for resale

loans.name: Lillian Kamya Group

texts.en: K. Lillian is the leader of the Concerned group in Kyengera, Uganda. She is 40 years old and the mother of school-age children; she also cares for two orphans. Lillian is a tailor who makes high-fashion clothes in her shop and also operates a bridal shop where she sells all sorts of accessories pertaining to a bride. She is a very stylish lady and is well known in her area. Lillian also creates party wear and makes different designs depending on her customers’ taste. She plans to use her portion of the group loan to buy material for making her clothes as well as cosmetics and other accessories for her bridal shop.

loans.use: Material for a tailor business and inventory for a bridal shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy sacks of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Lucila Berta

texts.es:
Lucila Berta Salmerón C. tiene la edad de 48 años, su estado civil es casada, Doña Lucila tiene 1 hijo menor de la edad de 17 años actualmente cursa el 4 año de secundaria, su compañero de vida labora por cuenta propia, sus propósitos son superar con su negocio ya que la mayoría de sus clientes necesitan calidad en la elaboración de sus trajes y uniformes ya que hay muchas costureras que brindan el servicio y no se preocupan por complacer al cliente en lo que piden Doña Lucila tiene los sueños de que su hija administre su negocio y adquiera  los conocimientos adecuados para la superación propia y de su familia ya que este le ayudara como otro medio de ingresos para su futuro sus deseos son que su hija logre coronar una carrera profesional par que su dependencia de vida no solo este ligada con el negocio de la costura si no que  además de poseer este medio de trabajo obtenga una carrera que pueda desempeñar Doña Lucila se siente orgullosa de su hija ya que ella le ayuda en lo mas necesario.

La actividad económica a la que se dedica es la costura y la venta de ropa, la ubicación de su negocio es en su casa de habitación en el Rpto San Carlos 2 calle, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es 6 años, Doña Lucila inicia este negocio por la necesidad de poseer otra fuente de ingresos ya que labora como docente en el colegio La Asunción ya que esta vendría a sustentar las necesidades de su hogar y de su familia por lo que decidió proponer  en su colegio la idea de que ella misma elaborara los uniformes y estos serian por encargos y fue así que obtuvo la oportunidad  de que el colegio donde Doña Lucila labora le facilitara su medio de trabajo por lo que esto le ayudo en la producción de sus uniformes por lo que poco a poco es que ha logrado aumentar y también por los financiamientos que ha hecho por medio de la Fundación León 2000 por lo que en al actualidad el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo ya que lo primero es la compra de materia prima como lo es: hilo,zipper, aguja, tela, tijeras y los utensilios necesarios para la elaboración de los uniformes que ya están en reservados para la entrada a clases de este colegio.
texts.en:
Lucila Berta Salmerón C. is 48 years old, is married, and has one child who is 17 years old. He is currently in his 4th year of high school. Her dream is to improve the quality of the clothing she makes. There are many seamstresses who offer services but don't care about making the customer happy. Lucila hopes her child takes over the business and that she gains the necessary knowledge to be able to run the business. She hopes she becomes successful in life and this would be the perfect career that would make her mother proud. Lucida does clothing repair and sells clothes. She currently runs her business from her home, located in Rpto San Carlos 2 Calle. She's had her business for 6 years. She began this business going because of the economic need she had at the moment. At the time she suggested making the uniforms for her child's school. (La Asuncion), the school loved the idea and gave her the task of creating these. She was able to increase her earning a bit at a time. She's been getting her finance thru Fundación Leon 2000. At this time she hopes to get a loan in order to purchase: thread, zippers, needles,fabric, scissors, and other things needed to make the uniforms. Some customers have already placed their uniform orders for school year about to come.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: materials for making school uniforms

loans.name: Alijandra

texts.en: Alijandra C., is 51 years old and a resident of Canubay, Oroquieta City. She is a single parent who has been separated for 19 years, and she has devoted her life to her 2 kids and her business. She sells candy and sliced unripe mangoes. Her loyal customers are bystanders of the city plaza. One day, she decided to start selling charcoal to food stalls around the area and she was impressed with the return. Her goal is to be able to support her children. She plans to expand her business by adding additional capital to her charcoal retailing. Alijandra hopes that one day she'll have a permanent location for her store.

loans.use: additional capital for her ventured charcoal retailing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To supply her ready-to-wear clothing shop

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Para El Progreso Group

texts.en:
Carmen Isidra L. is the coordinator of a group called Mujeres Unidas por el Progreso. Her group has five members. The loan will be shared by the members of the group, who run various businesses. 

Carmen is 38 years old and single. She lives with her mother and three adult children; 20, 22, and 24 years old. She runs a small restaurant where she sells sandwiches, rice and meat, other dishes, and juices. She runs this business from home, and most of her clients live in her neighborhood. She has previously received three loans from Esperanza; this will be her fourth loan. With these loans she has been able to invest in a freezer and gas cylinder. Today she probably sells twice as much as she did before receiving her first loan in June of 2007. She would like to expand her business even further and hopes that one day she will be able to employ another person to help run the business. She thinks that her neighborhood is ready for a larger cafeteria. She would also like to make some home improvements and adds that she would like to find a boyfriend.

loans.use: To expand a restaurant

loans.name: Carmen Giuliana

texts.es:
Carmen es socia del Bancomunal Luz de la Esperanza. 

Carmen es soltera, es la mayor de cuatro hermanos, tiene 20 años, estudia en la universidad Turismo y Hoteleria se inicio en las ventas por catalogo para ayudarse con los gastos de sus estudios como fotocopias, tipeos, libros entre otros, vende productos  de belleza por catalogo, desde hace un año en la universidad, sus clientas son sus compañeras de estudio; su Papa trabaja como obrero en la universidad y los hijos de los trabajadores están beneficiados con  becas, pero ella tiene que esforzarse con buenas notas para mantener la beca, ella todos los días antes de ir a la universidad tiene que cocinar para sus hermanos por que su mama sale a trabajar en un mercado.  
Necesita un préstamo de 800 soles para tener un stock de productos, para cubrir pagos de las ventas que le hacen.  
También ha pasado dificultades en la universidad por cambio de currículo tuvo que llevar cursos nuevos atrasando su ciclo de estudio.
El sueño que tiene Carmen es viajar y trabajar en un crucero como barman.
texts.en:
Carmen is a member of the "Luz de Esperanza" communal bank. Carmen is single and the oldest of four siblings. She is 20 years old and studies at the Tourism and Hotel Management university. She started doing catalog sales to help with her school expenses, such as copies, transcribing services, and books, among others. She sells beauty products by catalog. She has been in the university for a year and her customers are her fellow students. Her father is a laborer at the university and the children of workers are given scholarships, which is why she tries hard to get good grades so she can keep her scholarship. Every day before going to school she has to cook for her brothers and sisters because her mother goes to work at the market. She needs a loan for 800 soles so she can have an inventory of products and to cover payments for the sales she makes. She has also had some difficulties at the university due to a change of curriculum which caused her to have to take some new courses and delayed the completion of her studies. Carmen´s dream is to travel and work as a barman on a cruise ship.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy an inventory of products.

loans.name: Ana Del Socorro

texts.es:
Ana del Socorro Salmerón C. tiene la edad de 60 años, su estado civil es soltera, Doña Ana tiene 1 hijo de la edad de 20 años y actualmente estudia y colabora en el negocio con su Mama, sus propósitos son mantener su negocio activo para seguir proporcionando a su familia una fuente de ingresos ya que como toda persona ansiosa de superación  ocupa este  medio de trabajo como supervivencia para ella y su familia sus sueños son de que su hijo establezca un negocio por su propia cuenta para que el adquiera experiencia en los negocios y el día de mañana pueda hacer frente a todo tipo de problemas y esto le ayudara a madurar para la vida misma los sueños de Doña Ana son que las personas del exterior aprecien su trabajo ya que una parte del procedimiento del bordado es hecho a maquina y la otra es hecho a mano y le gustaría que sus productos sean exportados al extranjeros para considerar la calidad de su trabajo ya que todo lo que a logrado ha sido por que es una mujer luchadora y trabajadora.

Su actividad económica es la de costurera la venta de ropa y elaboración de repostería, la ubicación de su negocio es en su casa de habitación que es la siguiente de la iglesia San José 175 vrs al este, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 30 años, Doña Ana inicia su actividad económica, después de haber nacido su único hijo y al ser abandonada por el por su compañero de vida es así que enfrenta el reto de llevar el sustento diario a su hijo recién nacido y a ella misma, sin embargo a pesar de estos retos fue acogida por su familia y con el apoyo de ellos decide iniciar ofreciendo los servicios de costurera a diferentes familias y amigos y a pesar de que este oficio lo aprendió a temprana edad lo utilizo como herramienta de trabajo debido al poco tiempo que tenia con su trabajo decide incursionar en el aprendizaje de la repostería actividad que la volvió como otro medio de ingresos y que hasta la fecha ha logrado mantener ambos negocio por lo que para ella fue muy difícil ya que sufría una enfermedad que asota a la gran mayoría de las mujeres nicaragüenses como es el cáncer de mama y pudo superarla aferrada a su fe espiritual y el amor de ver crecer a su hijo que dependía totalmente de ella quien no podía descuidar la actividad pues era el único sustento y así es como obtiene este medio de trabajo por lo que ahora pide el financiamiento para capitalizar su negocio ya que cuando se enfermo ocupo el capital de trabajo para compra los medicamentos para su salud ya que también necesita realizar la compra de materia  prima para la elaboración de los bordados y la repostería  y gratifica la ayuda que le ha proporcionado Fundación León 2000 y las diferentes organizaciones amigas.
texts.en:
Ana del Socorro S. C. is 60 years old. She has a 20-year old son who is in school and helps her with her business. Her goal is to maintain her business so that she can continue providing her family with a source of income. Like everyone eager to get ahead, she works hard in order to help both herself and her family. Her greatest hope is that her son will establish his own business so that he can gain experience and confront the problems that he will have to face in business, something that will help him all his life. Ana's hope for herself is that people outside her country will appreciate her embroidery work, part of which is machine-made and part hand-made. She would like her products to be exported abroad so that foreigners can appreciate the quality of her work. She wants them to know that she's succeeded because she's a strong and hard-working woman. Ana makes a living as a seamstress, making and selling clothes, and as a baker, making and selling baked goods. She operates the businesses from her house near the San Jose church. She started in business 30 years ago when she was abandoned by her partner after the birth of her son and faced the everyday challenge of feeding both herself and her baby. Despite the difficulties, her family took her in and, with their help, she was able to start a business, offering her sewing skills to family and friends. She also entered into a bakery apprenticeship, work that she turned to in order to supplement her earnings from her sewing business. She's managed to maintain both businesses, something that was especially hard for her because like most Nicaraguan women she's suffered from breast cancer. Despite her illness, she had to work because her businesses were her only source of income. Her faith and her love for her son sustained her while she was ill but the medicine that she had to buy exhausted her capital. She's applying for a loan to recapitalize her business and buy the basic materials she needs for her sewing and pastry businesses. She's grateful for the help that she has received from Fundacion Leonn 2000 and other associated organizations.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jackelina  Mayke

texts.es:
Jackelina es socia del Bancomunal Luz de la esperanza.

Jackelina es conviviente, tiene 28 años, dos hijos de 6 y 3 años en el colegio fe y alegría, ella  solo estudio hasta tercer año de primaria por que  sus padres se separaron, ella se dedica a cuidar a sus cinco hermanos  que iban a estudiar mientras que ella quedaba en casa y su mama salía a trabajar; Por ese motivo ella no aprendió a leer ni escribir correctamente sabe un poco y se equivoca con frecuencia con los números, su esposo la ayuda cuando llega del trabajo, él trabaja en construcción, Jackelina se dedica a la venta de ropa, le vende a sus conocidos. 
Necesita un préstamo de 1200 soles para la  comprar ropa y venderla  a sus vecinas.  
Desde que esta en Finca recibe consejos de su promotora de cómo llevar su negocio, aprendido la importancia de ser honestad en el negocio para no perder la clientela y aprendió a ser   de ser puntual en sus pagos.

El sueño de Jackelina es saber leer y escribir bien, por que su hija le pregunta y ella no sabe que dice en los libros,  le gustaría tener un Kiosco para vender ropa, y no  estar por las casas ofreciendo su mercadería.
texts.en:
Jackelina is a member of the "Luz de la Esperanza" communal bank. Jackelina lives with her partner, is 28 years old and has two children, 6 and 3 years old. She studied only up to the third grade of primary school because her parents separated and she took care of her five brothers and sisters, who studied while she stayed at home and her mother went off to work. For this reason she did not learn to read and write correctly. She knows a little and frequently makes mistakes with numbers. Her husband helps her when her arrives home from work; he works in construction. Jackelina sells clothing to her acquaintances.She needs a loan for 1200 soles to buy clothing to sell to her neighbors. Since she has been in Finca she has received advice on how to manage her business, learning the importance of being honest in business so as to not lose customers and learning to be punctual in her payments. Jackelina´s dream is to read and write well, because her when daughter asks her she does not know what it says in books. She would like to have a stand for selling clothing and not be going from house to house selling her merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing for resale.

loans.name: Moses' Group

texts.en:
M. Moses is one of the executive members of Ndwaddemutwe group in Lugazi, Uganda. He is a very hard working man who has operated a private clinic for more than 10 years. Moses has received medical training and his clinic treats people from his locality who cannot afford the high transportation costs to get medical care in a major trade center. He has all kinds of medication in his clinic that he buys from the pharmacies in Kayunga and Kampala where the prices are more favorable, allowing him to treat his patients at a lower rate.

Moses has a wife and children who work the family farm back in the village and this helps to reduce food costs. As one of his achievements, out of his savings he has purchased a plot in the trading center that should sell like a hot cake in the near future. He needs his portion of this group loan to help buy more medicines, including anti-malarial tablets and syrups, syringes, needles, and so on as needed in his village.

loans.use: To purchase medicines and equipment for a clinic.

loans.name: Victor

texts.en:
Victor provides the community with fresh food and other essential goods. The Esperanza Home Improvement team met with Victor, who asked for a loan to conduct modest repairs. Victor plans to install new doors and add windows to improve the customer experience.  He is an active member of the Bank of Hope and has successfully repaid several business loans.  

Please help us fund his renovations.  Thank you!

loans.use: House repair

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena is wonderful lady with a loving heart. She is happily married and has three wonderful children. She runs "Schucks Auto Supply," which stocks parts for cars and motorcycles. She will use part of this loan to   pour a cement floor in her home. Her husband will contribute a portion of his wages to help her repay this loan. Please help us to provide a cement floor for this wonderful family.

Thank you!

loans.use: A cement floor

loans.name: Mujeres Valientes Group

texts.en:
Jesula E. is a coordinator for Mujeres Valientes (Brave Women), of the Bank of Hope. Thirty women belong to Mujeres Valientes, and 20 of them have successfully repaid previous loans. Jesula's group has ten women. The loan will be shared among the members of the group, who run various businesses.

Jesula is 29 years old; her husband is 30. They have two girls, 11 and 12 years old. Jesula runs a business selling clothes and shoes. She usually buys her merchandise in Santiago and resells for a profit in Cabarete, which is a tourist destination. Her customers are from Haiti and the Dominican Republic. She does not sell to tourists because because she does not speak English. 

Jesula has repaid two loans from Esperanza. This will be her third loan. These loans made it possible for Jesula to start her business. She used her first loan to stock clothing. With the second loan, she branched out into shoes and expanded her clothing inventory. She plans to use the third loan to diversify her business further by stocking perfume and soap as well. 

In her spare time Jesula likes to read the Bible, and also books on child rearing and running a household. Her dream is to have her own shop in the center of Cabarete, where she could attract the tourist trade. Today she lives in a rented house, and she hopes that one day she will be able to buy her own house. She also hopes that her children will have an opportunity to study at the university.

loans.use: To buy perfume and soap for resale

loans.name: Unidos Por El Progreso Group

texts.en:
Juana B., a mother of three from Hato Mayor, is the leader of the Bank of Hope group called Unidos Por el Progreso.  The members of this group will share the loan and use it for their various businesses. 

Juana has a business selling ice cream and fruit and will use the loan to buy needed supplies such flour, oil, and peanuts.  She is having trouble finding a house of her own and would one day like to own her own cafeteria and support her children in their studies.  

Thanks for your interest in supporting this group!

loans.use: To buy oil, peanuts, and other supplies

loans.name: Jane Nanono Group

texts.en: N. Jane is the leader of the Mbuya group in Kamapala, Uganda. She is a strong and hard-working lady who is able to manage two businesses at her home in Mbuya. She sells tap water to residents around her home area as well as selling matooke (green bananas) to the same people. She buys the matooke from trucks that bring the bananas to the trading centers and uses a rented bicycle to transport them to her home, where she sells them both in bunches and in a heap per finger. The water is supplied by the National Water and Sewerage Cooperation and she clears her bill every month. She needs her portion of this group loan to buy more matooke for sale.

loans.use: To increase inventory.

loans.name: Mischel

texts.en: Mrs. Mischel S., 24 years of age, is married with two kids and lives in Usocan, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. With their simple abode, she works hard to support her family by buying and selling fish and other seafood products. Her husband also catches fish to add to her income. She wanted to make a good daily earning out from fish vending. She sells to a nearby town of Calamba and Plaridel market. Strong family ties are what motivates her to survive and be strong for her children. She greatest wish is to send all her children to school.

loans.use: Additional Capital for fish vending

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga is single. She lives in Kahovka and sells household retail items in one of the local markets. Olga launched her enterprise one year ago. She always wanted to be self-employed and run her own business. Her business has seen rapid growth in a year. Presently, Olga has about 30,000 Grivnas in working capital. Her net profit is about 3,000 Grivnas a month. 

Olga still has many milestones to pass on her road to success. She has to learn to adapt to each wave of change in the market world. However, Olga looks into the future with much optimism and confidence and is filled with bright ideas and plans. One of her current plans is to increase her turnover capital and generate additional profit with the help of a 5,000 Grivna loan.

loans.use: To generate additional profit

loans.name: Casimena

texts.en: Casimena has three children and runs a successful clothing store.  Her store, "Tienda Casimena," specializes in used clothing for women. The Esperanza Home Improvement team toured her house, and they verified that several cement walls need repair. Presently, the walls allow water to seep through several places in the kid's room.  Please help her by financing this loan.  Thank you!

loans.use: Wall Repair

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy poultry and cattle for his butcher shop

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia L. operates a colomado that provides for her five children. The colomado is actively expanding, which is great for business. However, this business expansion will impede on her family's living space, so she wants to build an addition for the kitchen. The Home Improvement Team was impressed how active Cecilia is in her Bank of Hope.

Please help us finance this addition for Cecilia's family!  Thank you!

loans.use: Build an indoor kitchen

loans.name: Ayeben (Soyez  Unies) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Ayében  est un regroupement de 6  femmes  qui ont longtemps cohabité ensemble. Elles ont en moyenne 31 ans, mariées et mères d’au moins 5  enfants, vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles dans le quartier Heremakono de Kimparana, Préfecture de San (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 Pour augmenter  leurs chiffres d’affaire afin de tirer le maximum de profit de leurs activités, ces femmes ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Le montant du premier prêt est de 50.000 FCFA, c’est un groupe qui est à son début de collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso. Elles mènent  deux activités (la vente de condiments comme  principale activité et la restauration comme  secondaire).  Elles se procurent de leurs  marchandises au grand marché de kimparana et kouroubadougou. Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter divers condiments destinés à la vente et à la restauration. Elles comptent réaliser en moyenne 40 000 CFA chacune avec ce prêt, elles vendent les condiments à la porte de leur maison pendant la journée et  pour la restauration elles ont des gargotes au marché. En dehors du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Ayében group is made up of six women who have lived together for a long time. They average 31 years of age, are married and have at least five children. They all live in traditional families in the neighbourhood of Heremakono in Kimparana, San Prefecture, in Mali. In order to increase their sales and maximize their profits, these women have decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso. Their first loan request is for 50,000 FCFA. This group is just beginning their collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso. They have two sources of income: the sale of condiments is their primary activity and catering is their secondary activity. They get their goods from the main market of Kimparana and Kouroubadougou. This loan will be used to buy an assortment of condiments for resale and for their catering business. They expect to earn an average of 40,000 FCFA each with this loan. They sell their condiments at the door of their home during the daytime and for their catering business they have diners in the market. Aside from repaying their loan, they will use a portion of their revenues to contribute to the household expenses.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments and ingredients for their food stalls.

loans.name: Isabel

texts.en: Isabel runs a local restaurant that provides her community with Dominican and Haitian food.  Her business is extremely successful, and she enjoys serving her satisfied customers.  This loan will allow her to build a new kitchen to expand her restaurant and provide more seating for customers.  Isabel is wonderful woman with a loving spouse.  Please help us finance her kitchen and expand her business!  Thank you!

loans.use: a new kitchen

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en: M. Mary is the chairperson of Tukolere wamu lending group in Masajja, Uganda. The group meets at her home. Mary has run a retail shop for over 9 years and the shop has never failed since she joined her group. Mary is a married lady with 6 children, 3 of whom are in school, and she cares for 4 dependents who are all in school. Her loans help her so much in her shop that she can pay the school fees and upkeep. She needs her portion of the group loan to help with restocking her shop with sugar, soap, salt, cooking oil, paraffin, eggs, and so much more .

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Badegna : La Parenté Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Badegna de l’association Sabaly de kimparana est composé de 5 femmes mariées, elles vivent dans de grandes familles avec une moyenne d’âge de 41 ans  et ont chacune 4 enfants. Ce groupe de femmes s’est spécialisé dans la vente de légumes et de condiments alimentaires.
 Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités les clientes ont décidé d’intégrer depuis maintenant trois ans le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont  à leur cinquième prêt de groupe (prêt solidaire).Tous les prêts précédents ont été remboursement sans difficulté.
Ce prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des légumes frais (bananes Plantain, patate douce, igname  et autres) à Sikasso, koury et Bobo  qui seront revendus au fur et à mesure car ne peuvent être stockés pour longtemps. Elles revendent au marché de kimparana,  à la maison, au carrefour et dans les marchés voisins  comme San, Koury et Tominia.
Elles prétendent avoir un bénéfice de 120 000 F CFA avec ce prêt. Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt  et faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The "Badegna" group of the Sabaly association of Kimparana is made up of five married women. They live in large families, average 41 years of age and each have four children. This group of women specializes in selling vegetables and condiments. To increase the size of their businesses, these clients decided three years ago to join the loans program of Soro Yiriwaso with which they are now on their fifth group loan. All previous loans were fully repaid. This loan will allow them to buy fresh vegetables such as plantains, sweet potatos, yams among others in Sikasso, Koury and Bobo to retail over time as they do not keep long. They sell at the Kimparana market, at home, at crossroads, and in neighbouring marketplaces such as San, Koury and Tominia. They believe they will make a profit of 120,000 FCFA thanks to this loan. This profit will be used to repay the loan interest and to contribute to the household expenses.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetables and condiments.

loans.name: Valentina

texts.es:
Valentina  es socia del Bancomunal Luz de la Esperanza. 
Valentina Tiene 43 años, es separada, tiene dos hijos de 12 y 7 años, estudia en el colegio Ella es cuzqueña, ella empieza a trabajar desde los 16 años en diferentes oficios.
Estando ya casada trabajo en una  casa atendiendo un anciano, todo el día pero descuidada a sus hijos y tuvo que renunciar, y  decidió vender  sanwish en la puerta de su casa  por las noches de 7pm –11 pm, y por las mañanas estaba desocupada, un tío le propuso entrar en sociedad para vender menús ella  acepto el negocio y vende en el mercado modelo de villa el salvador.  

Desde que esta en Finca se siente más segura por que se siente respaldada por que encuentra orientación para su negocio, ha  logrado comprar  su carro sanwichero, una vitrina, y ampliar su negocio.
Necesita un préstamo de 1200 soles, para invertir en la compra de saco de papas, salchichas, aceite, platos descartadles.    
El sueño de Valentina es seguir trabajando y lograr que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Valentina is a member of the Luz de la Esperanza Community Bank. Valentina is 43 years old, is separated, and has two children who are 12 and 7 years old and in school. She is a Cuzcan and she began working 16 years ago in different positions. When married, she worked in a home attending to an elderly person all day. However, she neglected her children and had to give up that job. She decided to sell sandwiches in the entry of her house at night from 7-11PM and in the mornings, she was unemployed. An uncle proposed that she go into town to sell her menus. She accepted the business and she sells in the model market of Villa El Salvador. Since being in Finca, she feels more secure since she feels supported since she finds guidance for her business. She has managed to buy a sandwich cart, a glass case, and to grow her business. She needs a loan of 1,200 soles to invest in the purchase of a bag of potatoes, sausages, oil, and disposable plates. Valentina's dream is to continue working and to see her children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She needs a loan of 1,200 soles to invest in the purchase of a bag of potatoes, sausages, oil, and disposable plates.

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
Lucena P. is 54 years old, married, and has 7 children. She lives with her family in Danao, Plaridel, in Misamis Occidental. She helps with the family fishing business. By selling their seafood products, her family has been able to support itself and bring their catch to the closest local market.

Lucena has successfully completed her eighth loan, and is considered a Member in Good Standing. She hopes to expand her business once more with another loan. Faced with various challenges, she believes that your financial help can help her reach her goal.

Lucena never considers herself too old to strive for a better life. With her children and husband, she dreams of expanding her business and hopes to help her children find stable, consistent jobs.

loans.use: To build up additional capital for fishing

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
Victoria es socia del Bancomunal Luz de la Esperanza  
Victoria es casada tiene 39 años, tiene 2 hijos de 10 y 15 años ambos estudian en el colegio Alfonso Ugarte; Ella es de Ayacucho llego a Lima cuando tenia 6 años solos pudo estudiar la primaria por que su papa murió y tuvo que trabajar para sus siete hermanos, y se crió con una familia, donde trabajó cocinando,  hasta que se caso, consiguió trabajo en una peluquería por seis años aprendió a cortar cabello, teñir, después se retiro, decidió abrir una bodega en su casa “Bodega Miriam” lamentablemente el lunes pasado sufrió un robo, se llevaron el todo su dinero que tenia en caja, pero ella no se desanima sigue adelante.

Desde que llego a Finca ha recibido orientación para su negocio, aprendió la puntualidad y ha ser solidaria con las personas.  
Necesita un préstamo de 1600 soles para comprar abarrotes para surtir su bodega, como arroz, leche, aceite, azúcar, harina y  cerveza. 
El sueño que tiene es superarse y que sus hijos terminen de estudiar, ayudar a su mama que esta enferma  de  reumatismo en Ayacucho.
texts.en:
Victoria is a member of the Bancomunal Luz de la Esperanza ("Light of Hope Communal Bank") . Victoria is a 39-year-old married woman with 2 children who are 10 and 15 years old. Both of them study at the Alfonso Ugarte High School. She is from Ayacucho and came to Lima when she was only 6 years old. She was only able to attend elementary school before her dad died, and she had to work to support her seven siblings. She was raised in a family where she did the cooking until she got married. She found work in a hairdresser shop. For seven years, she learned to cut and dye hair. Afterwards, she retired and decided to open up a store out of her home called "Bodega Miriam". Unfortunately, last Monday she was robbed, and they took all the money in the cash register, but she continues to persevere and is not discouraged. Since she came to Finca, she has received advice about her business. She has learned about punctuality and how to be supportive of others. She needs a loan of 1600 soles to buy groceries for her store, like rice, milk, oil, sugar, flour, and beer. Her dream is to improve her situation, to see her children finish their studies, and to help her mom, who lives in Ayacucho and suffers from rheumatism.

Translated from Spanish by Tara Binetti, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She needs a loan of 1600 soles to buy groceries for her store, like rice, milk, oil, sugar, flour, and beer.

loans.name: Ana

texts.en: Ana is the mother of four exciting children.  Her business is a "comedor" (restaurant) that serves Dominican food.  She supports her family with her income.  The "comedor" also allows her to work from home and take care of the children.  With this loan, Ana will build a bathroom in the house for the family.  Please proviD. dignity and privacy for this wonderful family!  Thank you!

loans.use: Bathroom

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Aurea Laura

texts.es:
Laura es socia del Bancomunal Luz de la Esperanza. 
Laura es conviviente, tiene 49 años, cuatro hijos de 33,21,13 y 9 años, los dos mayores trabajan y los dos últimos estudian en el colegio Próceres en Surco. 
Ella tiene un negocio con su esposo  “A Y Q”  TELECON  servicio de telecomunicación.
Antes de poner su negocio ella vendía comida en el mercado de frutas, y su esposo trabajaba como técnico electricista en  telefónica por muchos años hasta que renuncio y con los ahorros  puso un negocio de telecomunicaciones, empezó poco a poco, ella deja la venta de menú y ahora es la recepcionista de su negocio.  

Desde que comenzó en Finca recibieron orientación, clases de cómo llevar una empresa, como atender al cliente, consejo de la promotora que les dice  es mejor pensar con la cabeza no con el corazón, todas las enseñanzas las aplica a su negocio.
Necesita un préstamo de 1200 Soles para invertirlos en la compra de cables, canaletas, intercomunicadores. 
Laura tiene un sueño que es poner en su casa un locutorio Internet, o una librería bazar.
texts.en:
Laura is a member of the Village Bank Luz de la Esperanza. She is 49 years old and lives with her partner and four children, ages 33, 21, 13 and 9. The two oldest work and the two youngest study at the school Próceres in Surco. She and her husband have a telecommunication business called "A and Q" TELECON. Before starting this business she sold food in the fruit market and her husband worked as an telephone electrician. They worked for many years at these jobs until they saved enough to resign and start their new telecom business. They began little by little, with Laura working as the receptionist. Since they have been involved with Kiva partner FINCA Peru, they have received guidance and classes on business management and client service. They have learned it is better to think with the head than the heart, and have applied all these lessons to their business. Laura requires a loan of 1200 soles to purchase cables, cable trunking, and intercoms. She hopes that she will eventually be able to run an internet cafe or a bookstore.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Martyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase materials for telecommunications business

loans.name: Klara

texts.en:
Klara is married with two grown-up children. She sells decoration articles and souvenirs at a market in Beregovo city. Her profit is about 3,500 UAH per month.

Klara has been in this business for 5 years. She offers her customers good quality products at affordable prices. Good location and a large assortment are keys to Klara's business success.

Klara would like to receive a loan of 7,000 UAH to increase her inventory. Her goal is to develop this business even more and attract even more customers.

loans.use: to increase the assortment

loans.name: Paulina

texts.es:
Paulina es socia del Bancomunal Luz de la Esperanza 
Paulina es de Junín, de la bella ciudad de Tarma, es casada, tiene 50 años, cinco hijos mayores que trabajan y estudian;  llega a Lima por que a su esposo lo trasladan en su trabajo, ella decidió salir a vender en un mercado como ambulante gelatina y  marcianos, cada vez vendía mas, alquilo un pequeño puesto  y también empezó a vender jugos, ahora ella es propietaria de su puesto  han pasado veinte años y su esfuerzo valió la pena. 

Desde que entro en Finca ha aprendió hacer responsable en la puntualidad de sus pagos, le gusta las charlas que recibe de cómo mejorar su negocio.
Necesita un préstamo de 1800 soles, para ampliar su negocio y comprar artefactos como licuadora, vitrina y vender mas cosas. 
El sueño que tiene es que sus ahorros crezcan mas, para poder construir de material noble su puesto en el mercado.
texts.en:
Paulina is a member of the Village Bank Luz de la Esperanza. She is from Junín, in the beautiful city of Tarma, and is fifty years old and married, with five grown children who are working and studying. She came to Lima because her husband was transferred by his job, and she decided to work in the market selling gelatin desserts on foot. She began selling more and more, and rented a small booth where she began to also sell juice. She now owns her booth and has spent twenty years there; all of her effort has been worth it. Since she has joined Kiva partner FINCA Peru she has learned to be responsible with making punctual payments, and she enjoys the tips she gets on how to improve her business. She requires a loan of 1800 soles in order to expand her business and buy items such as a blender and a display case to generate more sales. She hopes to save enough money to build a more durable booth in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Martyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a blender, a display case, and other items to improve sales

loans.name: Raiza

texts.en: Raiza is a mother of four who operates a store selling anything and everything.  She is an entrepreneur and allows her customers to dictate her inventory.  Her loan will build a internal bathroom for her family.  Please help us finance a new bathroom for her family!  Thank you!

loans.use: build a bathroom

loans.name: Barbara

texts.es:
Bárbara es socia del Bancomunal  Luz D. la esperanza 
Bárbara tiene 60 años, es casada tiene tres hijos mayores D. 35,33 y 25 años todos sus hijos están casados.
Ella llega a lima a los 18 años con un compadre D. su papá, empezó  a trabajar en  las casas, hasta que se caso, se dedico a la venta D. ropa en un  mercado como ambulante, hasta que le robaron toda su mercadería decidió no vender mas,  y en la puerta D. su casa se puso a vender comida esto lo hizo por muchos años después se canso y empezó a criar chanchos,  los llevaba a vender en la chancheria, llego a tener diez chanchos,  llegándoles a vender todos, y junto con su esposo hace ocho años pusieron un taller D. carpintería que  funciona  en su casa, ella ayuda en lo que pueD.. 
DesD. que comenzó en Finca su vida ha cambiado, le gusta las reuniones, se distrae, tiene mas amigas. 

Necesita un préstamo D. 1400 soles para ampliar su carpintería, construirla un poco, comprar materiales como tripley, terocal, cola.
El sueño D. Bárbara es que sus hijos tengan mejores trabajos, y agrandar su taller D. carpintería.
texts.en:
Barbara is a member of the Village Bank Luz D. la Esperanza. She is 60 years old and married with three adult children, aged 35, 33, and 25, all of whom are married. She came to Lima at the age of 18 with a friend of her father and worked cleaning houses until she married. She sold clothing on foot in a market, until all of her merchandise was stolen and she decided to find a new profession. Barbara began to sell food from her home, which she did for many years until she tired of it and started raising pigs and selling them to the butcher's shop. She raised ten pigs, and sold them all. Eight years ago she and her husband build a carpentry workshop in their home, in which she helps when she can. Since Barbara joined Kiva partner FINCA Peru her life has changed. She enjoys the meetings, she has fun, and she has more friends. She requires a loan of 1400 soles in order to expand the workshop - to do some building and purchase materials like wood scraps and glue. Her dream is that her children will have better jobs and she she will enlarge her carpentry workshop.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Martyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To expand her carpentry workshop

loans.name: Mercedes Espirita

texts.es:
Mercedes es socia del Bancomunal Luz de la Esperanza.
Mercedes es conviviente, tiene 36 años y tres hijos 15, 14, y 5 años todos estudian en el colegio Ollantay.
A Mercedes siempre le gustado el negocio, hoy en día tiene una pequeña tienda se llama “Mechita “pero ella empezó vendiendo  salchi-papas en la puerta de su casa con al ayuda de sus hijos, y cuando hay campeonatos de deporte por su barrio sale a vender tallarín con chanfainita, su esposo es guardián en una construcción. 
Desde que esta en Finca a progresado económicamente, su casita era de esteras ahora es de madera, esta muy contenta, aprendió a separar el negocio de las amistades, a no gastarse su capital de trabajo, y darle buen uso a sus ganancias.

Necesita un préstamo de 1200, soles para surtir la pequeña tienda que funciona en su casa y comprar abarrotes como, leche, arroz, aceite y gaseosas.    
El sueño de ella es tener un negocio de restaurante, con sus hijos por que le gusta la cocina; y que Finca siga ayudando a más mujeres.
texts.en:
Mercedes is a member of "Bancomunal Light of Hope". Mercedes is 36 years old, and lives with her partner and her three children, ages 15, 14, and 5 years who all study at Ollantay school. Mercedes has always liked business. These days, she has a small shop called "Mechita", but she began selling by "salchipapas" (a fast food dish consisting of hot dog and potatoes) from the door of her house with the help of her children. When there are sports championships in her neighborhood, Mercedes sells noodles. Her husband is a building custodian. Since she has been with Finca (the microfinance partner), Mercedes has progressed economically. Her house was previously made of wooden mats, and is now made of wood. Mercedes is very happy. She has learned to separate business from friendship, not to spend her working capital, and put her profits to good use. Mercedes needs a loan of 1,200 Peruvian Soles to stock up the small shop that she runs from her house, and buy groceries like milk, rice, oil and soft drinks. Her dream is to start a restaurant business with her children as she likes to cook, and that Finca continues to help more women.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Lucas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Ivelisse

texts.en: Ivelisse is wonderful lady, who lives in the Dominican countryside.  She operates a town "colomado" that provides food and supplies to the community. This loan will provide new walls and doors for her store.  Thank you for supporting Ivelisse!

loans.use: Repair a little store building

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy sacks of corn, millet, beans, and peanuts for resale

loans.name: Juma's Group

texts.en: N. Juma is a member of Kyosiga group in Kayunga, Uganda.  He is a married man with 8 children, 6 of whom are in school, while he caters for 5 young orphans that stay with his mother in the village. He is a butcher selling all sorts of meat including beef and goat, as well as a farmer growing maize, beans, cassava, and coffee.  At the same time, he has a motorcycle ‘boda boda’ taxi business. He has over 20 years of experience in all his businesses and he has been so successful because of the loans that help to push him further and the help of his wife who works with him. He needs his portion of the group loan to help with running all his businesses.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for a butcher shop and seeds for farming.

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is divorced. She sells women's clothing and shoes at the central market in Beregovo. Her income is about 2,500 UAH per month.

Irina has been in this business for 10 years already. She likes selling women's clothing and likes working with customers. Irina's customers like buying from her as well. Besides that, her good location at the central market provides stable income.

Irina is asking for a loan of 8,500 UAH to increase the assortment of her goods. Irina hopes to increase her sales and spend the extra profit to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to increase the assortment of her goods

loans.name: María

texts.es: María tiene 37 años, vive con su único hijo, Neo, de 12 años, y con su madre anciana de 72 años; en la casa de su madre. Durante toda su vida de dedicó a labrar la tierra, se levanta a las 4.00am para preparar el desayuno y el almuerzo, antes de salir de casa rumbo a sus chacra les da de comer sus animales, cuyes y conejos que cría para cuando esté baja la venta de sus productos, vende estos animales. En esta oportunidad está sembrando papa y arvejas, para lo cual contrata a 10 o 12 peones a quienes les paga diario 15 soles, incluido el almuerzo.  Mientras tanto su madre e hijo pastean sus vacas que cría con la misma intención que sus conejos y cuyes. Una vez que termina de cultivar su chacra el resto de los días se dedica a pastar sus animales, María está muy contenta con su trabajo. Este es su 4to préstamo consecutivo que tiene con MFP, y todo este tiempo, aunque ella no tiene tiempo de asistir a las reuniones, las fechas cuando debe pagar las cuotas envía a su madre a la reunión para que pague su cuota y no caer en morosidad. El dinero que solicita es para la compra de fertilizantes e insecticidazas.
texts.en:
María is 37 years old and lives with her only son, 12 year old Neo, and her elderly 72 year old mother in her mother’s home. All her life she has farmed. She gets up at 4 AM to prepare breakfast and lunch before leaving her home on the way to her farm she feeds her animals – guinea pigs and rabbits that she raises so that when her products sales are low she sells these animals. At the moment she is planting potatoes and peas, for which she hires 10-12 workers whom she pays 15 soles daily, and includes lunch. Meanwhile her mother and son take care of the cows which she raises with the same purpose as the guinea pigs and rabbits. María is very content with her work. This is her 4th loan with MFP, and all this time, even though she didn’t have time to attend the meetings, the dates when she should make her payments she sends her mother to the meeting to pay her payment and not fall behind in her debt. The money she seeks will be used to buy fertilizer and insecticide.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and insecticide.

loans.name: Bendiya (Fruit De L’Entente) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Bendiya de l’association Sabaly kimparana est constitué de 4 femmes qui se connaissent il y’a des années pour la pratique de la même activité. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans et ont chacune 4 enfants au moins et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles dans la préfecture de San, région de Ségou(quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Vendeuses de condiments alimentaires, pour transformer leurs rêves en réalité ces femmes avaient besoin d’un appui financier. C’est ainsi qu’elles ont sollicité Soro Yiriwaso depuis 3 ans maintenant. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt après le remboursement intégral des 4 précédents. Elles se procurent des marchandises au marché de kimparana en gros et revendent en détail sur place, à la maison et devant la porte de leurs maisons.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des sacs d’oignons de piments et divers condiments avec les paysans pour les revendre.
Les membres du groupe Bendiya se propose d’avoir un bénéfice de 90 000 FCFA chacun avec ce prêt.
le bénéfice obtenu sera utilisé pour rembourser l’intérêt du prêt et faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Dans les jours à venir les membres du groupe Bendiya veulent renforcer leur partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso afin d’avoir un montant de prêt élevé et diversifier les marchandises.
texts.en:
The "Bendiya" group of the Sabaly Kimparana association is made up of four women who have known one another for many years as they have the same type of business. They average 40 years of each and each have at least four children and live in traditional families in the San Prefecture, in the region of Ségou in Mali. They sell condiments. In order to make their dreams come true, these women need financial help. This is why they have been working with Soro Yiriwaso for three years now. This is their fifth loan, having repaid all four previous loans in full. They buy their goods in bulk at the market of Kimparana and retail them in the same market, from home and in front of their homes. This current loan will be used to buy bags of onions, peppers and various condiments from farmers to resell. The "Bendiya" group members expect to make a profit of 90,000 FCFA each thanks to this loan. The profits will be used to pay back the interest on the loan and to contribute to the household expenses. In the future, the members of this group want to reinforce their partnership with Soro Yiriwaso in order to borrow a greater amount and diversify their merchandise.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seasonings/condiments.

loans.name: Teodosia

texts.es: Teodosia tiene 39 años, convive con su pareja cerca de 20 años, en los cuales tuvo 2 hijos que viven con ellos en su casa propia. Sus padres fueron personas que se dedicaron a la agricultura, desde entonces ella aprendió los gajes de esta labor, en un inicio, ella y su esposo sembraban en chacras alquiladas, y luego han ido adquiriendo sus propios terrenos, donde ahora siembran papa y arvejas, pero para el cultivo de sus flores siguen alquilando.  En este momento están sembrado arveja, mientras que su esposo desde muy temprano prepara la tierra, Teodosia cocina el almuerzo, que lleva juntamente con sus animales, lo cuales sujeta en lugares donde exista mucho pasto, para ella involucrarse en las faenas de la chacra. Al finalizar el mes va diseminar las semillas para el cultivo de gladiolos. Teodosia se enteró de MFP debido a que sus vecinos pertenecían a un banco comunal donde accedían a créditos, entonces ella y otros vecinos se han organizado para formar su propio grupo, con el que tienen su primer préstamo, y han hecho compromisos de paga para no caer en morosidad. Con el dinero solicitado comprará semilla de arvejas e insecticidas contra la plaga de gusanos que ataca la papa.
texts.en:
Teodosia is 39 years old and lives with her husband of 20 years and her 2 children in their own home. Her parents were farmers, so she learned the all the facets of this work. In the beginning she and her husband planted on rented fields, and then they slowly acquired their own property where they now grow potatoes and peas, but for growing their flowers they continue to rent. Today they are planting peas. While her husband prepares the land in the early morning, Teodosia cooks lunch which she takes along with her animals to where there is a lot of pasture so they can be involved in working the land as well. At the end of the month she is going to plant gladiolas. Teodosia approached MFP because her neighbors belonged to a communal bank where they were able to access loans, so she and other neighbors have organized to form their own group, with which they have their first loan and have made some commitments not to fall behind in their payments. With the money she will buy pea seeds and insecticides to fight the worm that attacks the potatoes.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy seeds and insecticides

loans.name: Primitiva

texts.es: Primitiva acaba de cumplir 37 años, hace exactamente 14 años viene conviviendo con su pareja, con el que tiene 3 hijos y viven en su casa propia. Al iniciar su matrimonio, tenía la idea de tener una bodega, pero su esposo es agricultor, entonces tuvo que seguir con la misma labor para el sustento de su familia, luego su esposo tuvo la oportunidad de trabajar en el tendido de redes eléctricas en otra ciudad y Primitiva se quedó a cargo de sus chacras. Pese a que no le agradan las labores agrícolas se dedica con mucha entrega a cuidar y cultivar los terrenos sembrados por su esposo, asimismo quiere sembrar las semillas de papa que guardó su esposo, y lo hará con el apoyo de peones. Su esposo siempre tuvo fe y cree que es muy rentable la siembra de papa semilla, por ello Primitiva quiere continuar con la próxima siembra, después de cosechar este producto lo seleccionan de acuerdo al tamaño para la venta como semilla, ya que no es para consumo. Primitiva está muy contenta al saber que este banco comunal le brinda su apoyo, y por las facilidades de pago que tiene en MPF, y está comprometida a pagar las cuotas fijadas en las fechas exactas, para ganarse la confianza del grupo, ya que es su primer préstamo. El dinero que está solicitando es para comprar abono y concretizar la siembra de la papa semilla que tiene guardada.
texts.en:
Primitiva just turned 37. When she came to MFP exactly 14 years ago, she was living with her husband and their three children in her own home. When Primitiva was first married she had the idea of owning a small store, but her husband is a farmer and had to keep working the fields to support the family. Later he found a job hanging electrical wires in another city and Primitiva was left to care for the fields. She cultivated the crops planted by her husband and with the help of laborers she also planted potato seeds that her husband had stored. Primitiva's husband has always been a man of faith and she believes that planting potatoes is profitable. Even though her current crop won't be large enough to sell for food, Primitiva would like to sell it for seed and continue to plant potatoes for the next harvest. Primitiva is happy to know that this community bank supports her, and because of the ease of paying with MPF she is prepared to repay her loan on the exact dates specified. She'll do this to earn the confidence of the group, as this is her first loan. The money will go to buy fertilizer and to finish planting the potato seeds that she has saved.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es: Nancy tiene casi 31 años, viene conviviendo con su pareja cerca de 13 años con quien tiene 3 hijos, y en este tiempo han podido construir su casa propia donde viven ahora. Desde muy joven se dedica al labrado de la tierra, actividad heredada de sus padres, con la diferencia de que ellos sembraban grandes cantidades de papa, mientras que Nancy siembra arvejas en mayor cantidad, también las flores denominadas gladiolos, papa siembra solo para su consumo por ser de mayor inversión. Sembrar arvejas, para ella, es más rentable y se siente contenta porque ya conoce las reacciones de la planta y de acuerdo a ello lo fumiga las veces que lo requiere, si es posible semanalmente; lo curioso es que ella no solo siembra un solo tipo de semilla, sino que en una chacra un tipo y en otra chacra otra semilla, en todos sus años de agricultora hizo esta dinámica y le fue muy bien, la dificultad es cuando varían los precios del mercado y en épocas muy extremas no llega a recuperar los gastos realizados. Este es el primer préstamo de Nancy con MFP, está muy entusiasmada por pertenecer a unos de los bancos comunales, haciendo el compromiso pagar puntualmente. Con el dinero solicitado comprará semilla de arvejas, un tipo cuesta 472 soles y la otra semilla, 380 soles, con el resto del dinero piensa comprar insecticidas para fumigar las arvejas una vez que hayan germinado y brotado las hojas.
texts.en:
Nancy is nearly 31 years old and has lived with her partner for 13 years. They have three children and have built their own home, where they now live. Nancy has been a farmer since she was young, a profession that she inherited from her parents. Her parents planted large quantities of potatoes, but Nancy now grows peas. She also plants flowers such as gladiolas, as well as potatoes for her family to eat. For Nancy, growing peas is very profitable and she's happy because she knows how to care for the plants. By watching her crop Nancy knows when to fumigate, and she does so weekly when possible. Nancy's unique approach is to plant a different type of seed in each field, something that she's done for her entire career and has worked well for her. The difficult part of being a farmer is the varied market prices, and in extreme times she's not able to recoup her costs. This is Nancy's first loan with MFP and she is excited to belong to a community bank. She has agreed to pay promptly and will use the money to buy pea seeds. One type of seed costs 472 soles and another type costs 380 soles. With the rest of the money Nancy hopes to buy insecticides to fumigate the peas once they've germinated and opened their leaves.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy seeds and insecticides

loans.name: Benkadi (L’Entente Est Bonne). Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi est un regroupement de quatre femmes du quartier Dar-Salam 2 de la ville de Koutiala (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali) qui se sont connues depuis des années. Mariées et mères d’au moins 4 enfants, elles ont en moyenne 45 ans et vivent toutes dans de grandes familles. 
Elles mènent presque une seule  activité qui est  la vente de céréales  (la vente de mil, maïs    soja, haricot, etc..). Elles ont de l’expérience dans la vente de céréales
Dans le souci d’augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis six mois. Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des sacs de mil, maïs et soja pour les revendre.
Elles s’approvisionnent avec les paysans dans les foires des villages environnants et les revendent à leur tour sur place dans les marchés de la ville de Koutiala.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser en moyenne 70 000 FCFA de bénéfice chacune. Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et faire face aux charges courantes de la famille.
Dans l’avenir, le groupe compte obtenir chacun un prêt élevé pour l’ouverture d’un magasin de stockage de céréales et  élargir leurs activités.
texts.en:
The Benkadi group is made up of four women from the Dar-Salam 2 neighbourhood of the city of Koutiala in Mali. These women have known each other for many years. They are married and have at least four children each; they average 45 years of age and all live in large families. They have one main activity: the sale of cereals such as millet, corn, soya beans, beans, and so on. They are experienced at selling cereals. In order to expand their businesses, the members decided to join the loans program of Soro Yiriwaso six months ago. This loan will be used to buy bags of millet, corn and soya beans for resale. They buy their cereals from farmers at the markets of neighbouring villages and retail locally in the markets of Koutiala. They expect to make an average profit of 70,000 FCFA each thanks to this loan. This profit will be used to repay the interest on the loan and to contribute to the household expenses of their respective families. In the future, this group plans to borrow a greater amount in order to open a warehouse to store their cereals and expand their businesses.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cereals for resale.

loans.name: Margaret Nanyonjo Group

texts.en: N. Margaret is one of the members of her group. She is a businesswoman selling fresh fruits and vegetables that she buys from Owino and Kibuye markets and sells from her stall just next to her home in Kyengera. She is a mother of two and she needs her portion of the group loan to be able to increase the variety of her inventory by including the sale of curry powder, salt, ginger, green peppers, and Irish potatoes for increased income, hence more savings.

loans.use: To increase the variety of inventory.

loans.name: Shalom Group

texts.en:
Amelia C., mother of three and leader of the Bank of Hope Shalom, lives in Hato Mayor and works with fabric. She hopes this loan will help her grow her business and be able to upgrade locations where she would be able to manufacture and hire workers to help her.

Thanks for your interest in this group!

loans.use: Supplies and fabric for business

loans.name: Flor

texts.es: Flor tiene 34 años, empezó a convivir con su pareja desde que tuvo 14 años y fruto de esa relación marital tiene 4 hijos, viven en el Pueblo de Cumutay, donde han construido su casa de adobe y piensan en empastar con yeso para que quede mucho mejor. A los 15 años ya era madre de su hija Jenny, desde entonces se levantaba muy temprano, a las 5.00am juntamente con su suegra para ayudarla a preparar el almuerzo para los trabajadores de la chacra, y una vez que fue creciendo su hija mayor, ya iba a apoyar a la chacra. Después de varios años de trabajar para sus suegros, decidieron cultivar con chacras alquiladas sus propios productos, después sus suegros les dieron unos terrenos, donde ahora siembran papa y arvejas en grandes cantidades y poco a poco ya están comprando más terrenos de cultivo. La agricultura le es muy rentable y está muy contenta, porque se da tiempo para todo, la dificultad que tienen en estos tiempos es la lluvia, temen que pueda provocar la plaga a las arvejas, en el caso de la papa la lluvia no les deja cosechar, ya que si la guardan húmeda se irá pudriendo. Flor ya viene trabajando por cuarta vez consecutiva un crédito con MFP, y todo este tiempo ha demostrado ser una cliente muy responsable en sus pagos, asimismo asiste a todas las reuniones del banco comunal. El dinero que está solicitando es para la compra de sacos de abono, cada uno cuesta 115 soles, también comprará insecticidas para las arvejas, lo que calcula le costará cerca de 350 soles.
texts.en:
Flor is 34 years old and she's been living with her partner since she was 14. Now she and her husband have four children and they live in the Cumutay villiage. They've built their own adobe house and hope to fill it with plaster so that it is more stable. Flor was a mother at age 15 and since then she's woken up at 5am to help her mother-in-law make lunch for the farm workers. Once her eldest daughter began to grow up, Flor was able to help on the farm. After several years of working for her husband's parents, she began to cultivate her own crops on rented land. Later her husband's parents gave Flor and her husband some land, where they now grow potatoes and peas in large quantities. Little by little they're able to buy more arable land. Farming is profitable and Flor is happy with her work because it gives her time to do everything. The challenge during this time of year is rain, and Flor and her husband fear that it could create a plague for the pea crop. Too much rain ruins the potato harvest, because if the potatoes hold water they'll rot. Flor is in her fourth loan cycle with MFP and she's shown herself to be a responsible client. She makes her payments on time and attends all of the community bank meetings. Flor will use the money to buy sacks of fertilizer, which cost 115 soles each. She'll also buy insecticides for the peas, which she calculates will cost 350 soles.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and insecticides

loans.name: Julia Carlota

texts.es:
Julia es social del Bancomunal 24 de 0ctubre
Julia es casada, tiene 46 años y  tres hijos, los de 22, 21 y 16 años; los mayores están casados y el ultimo  estudia ingles. 

Ella cuando era joven estudio  para auxiliar de niños, llego a trabajar en un colegio por varios años hasta que se caso, y se dedico a criar a sus hijos, empezó a vender ropa en consignación pero el taller de donde sacaba  la ropa cerro y dejo de vender ropa. 
actualmente Julia  esta sola en Lima por que su esposo se fue a trabaja en el extranjero desde hace 6 meses, animada por una amiga, entra a la venta de productos de belleza por catalogo,
Desde que comenzó en Finca  ha aprendido a como vender su producto y como sacar el capital y no gastárselo, y sacar la ganancia, también aprende de las experiencias de las  socias  en el Bancomunal 
Necesita un préstamo de 800 soles, para compra productos  de belleza por catalogo en oferta, y poder estoquearse. 
El sueño  de Julia es tener una librería bazar.
texts.en:
Julia is a member of "Bancomunal 24th of October". She is 46 years old, and married with three children, ages 22, 21 and 16 years. The older children are married, and the youngest studies English. When she was young, Julia studied to help children, and worked in a school for several years until she got married, at which point she focused on raising her children. Julia started selling clothes on consignment, but the shop where she got the clothes from closed down and stopped selling clothes. Julia is currently alone in Lima, as her husband went to work abroad for 6 months. Encouraged by a friend, Julia began selling beauty products by catalog. Since she began at Finca, Julia has learned how to sell her product, how to save her capital instead of spending it, and has also learned from the experiences of other members of Bancomunal. Julia needs a loan of 800 Peruvian Soles to buy beauty products offered by catalog, and stock up. Julia's dream is to have a book bazaar.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Lucas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase beauty supplies for her sales inventory.

loans.name: Bartolina

texts.en: Bartolina is the matriarch of her family.  She operates a town "colomado" that provides food and other supplies to her community.  This loan will allow her family to expand their store and house.  As you can see in the photo it is a family business!  Please provide Barolina's family an opportunity to live in adequate conditions.  Thank you!

loans.use: Completely repair her colomado

loans.name: Jenny Cecilia

texts.es:
Jenny es social del Bancomunal 24 de 0ctubre
Jenny es conviviente, tiene 40 años, tres hijos de 17, 15, 4 años; ella estudio ingeniería industrial, no pudo acabar su carrera por que salió embarazada, al tiempo trabajo en la administración de un restaurante, le gusta el negocio de comida y después de dos años renuncia, con las visión de poner un negocio de comida, empezó a dar desayunos almuerzo en su casa, poco a poco fue comprando cocina, congeladora, platos. fuentes implementando todo para su negocio de comida y  Buffet  “J y M” Ketherine; que  funciona en su casa  hace siete años.
Jenny llega a estudiar varios cursos de cocina y después se puso a enseñar en la municipalidad de surco, por que ella trabaja en el afea de talleres productivos, empezó su negocio desde que entro en Finca, esta muy agradecida por todo lo que ha podido lograr con la ayuda de los prestamos y  la cultura de ahorro que aprendió,  Finca le dio un método, le gusta las reuniones del Bancomunal por que se relaciona con otras personas que tiene visión de negocio como ella.  

Necesita un préstamo de 3000 soles, para la compra de  menaje de cocina, copas, platos,   fuentes, cubiertos por que alquilarlos le sale  muy caro.
El sueño de Jenny es tener su casa propia, y junto  con sus hijos  seguir en el  negocio de buffet.
texts.en:
Jenny is a member of "Bancomunal 24th of October". She is 40 years old, and lives with her partner and her three children, ages 17, 15, and 4. Jenny studied industrial engineering, but could not finish her degree as she became pregnant and left school. Jenny then went to work in restaurant administration. She likes the food business, but quit after two years, with the vision of opening her own food business. Jenny started selling breakfast and lunch at her house, and little by little began buying food, a freezer, and plates to establish her restaurant "Buffet 'J and M' Ketherine", which she has been running in her home for the past seven years. Jenny has taken various cooking classes and began to teach in the municipality, as she works in the area of workshop production. She started her business when she began working with Finca (the microfinance partner). Jenny is very grateful for all that she has been to do with the help of loans and the culture of saving money that she learned. Finca gave Jenny a method to work with, and she likes the Bancomunal meetings where she can interact with other people who have a business vision like her own. Jenny needs a loan of 3,000 Peruvian Soles to purchase kitchen utensils, cups, plates, and cupboards, because renting these goods is very costly. Jenny's dream is to have her own home, and together with her children, continue with her restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Lucas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase material inventory for her restaurant.

loans.name: Benkadi (L’Union) Group

texts.fr:
Les six femmes du groupe Benkadi de l’association Sorotekoumbela du village de kimparana (préfecture de San quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali) se connaissent bien à travers leur association traditionnelle du village.
